The Power of Iterative Filtering for Supervised
Learning with (Heavy) Contamination

Adam R. Klivans klivans@cs.utexas.edu UT Austin Konstantinos Stavropoulos kstavrop@cs.utexas.edu UT Austin Kevin Tian kjtian@cs.utexas.edu UT Austin Arsen Vasilyan arsenvasilyan@gmail.com UT Austin Supported by NSF award AF-1909204 and the NSF AI Institute for Foundations of Machine Learning (IFML).Supported by the NSF AI Institute for Foundations of Machine Learning (IFML) and by scholarships from Bodossaki Foundation and Leventis Foundation.Supported by the NSF AI Institute for Foundations of Machine Learning (IFML).
Abstract

Inspired by recent work on learning with distribution shift, we give a general outlier removal algorithm called iterative polynomial filtering and show a number of striking applications for supervised learning with contamination:

  1. 1.

    We show that any function class that can be approximated by low-degree polynomials with respect to a hypercontractive distribution can be efficiently learned under bounded contamination (also known as nasty noise). This is a surprising resolution to a longstanding gap between the complexity of agnostic learning and learning with contamination, as it was widely believed that low-degree approximators only implied tolerance to label noise.

  2. 2.

    For any function class that admits the (stronger) notion of sandwiching approximators, we obtain near-optimal learning guarantees even with respect to heavy additive contamination, where far more than 1/2121/21 / 2 of the training set may be added adversarially. Prior related work held only for regression and in a list-decodable setting.

  3. 3.

    We obtain the first efficient algorithms for tolerant testable learning of functions of halfspaces with respect to any fixed log-concave distribution. Even the non-tolerant case for a single halfspace in this setting had remained open.

These results significantly advance our understanding of efficient supervised learning under contamination, a setting that has been much less studied than its unsupervised counterpart.

1 Introduction

Dataset curation is a fundamental part of the training pipeline of modern machine learning models and often appears to be the bottleneck in obtaining models with improved performance [86, 82, 8, 47]. One way to theoretically model this problem is to assume that the learner has access to aâ€”potentially heavilyâ€”contaminated dataset and the goal is to learn a model that performs well on some clean underlying target distribution. While there has been tremendous recent progress for unsupervised learning with contamination [56, 21, 75, 76, 6, 39, 55, 15, 84, 5, 20, 9, 58, 90, 31, 26], relatively little is known for supervised learning with contamination, especially for binary classification.

Many efficient algorithms with strong error guarantees have been developed for agnostic learning, a special case of contamination where only the labels are adversarially corrupted [68, 74, 11, 1, 38, 41, 32]. Most of these guarantees, however, had seemed difficult to extend to the more challenging setting of contamination, where both labels and covariates can be adversarially corrupted. In this paperâ€”building on recent work on robust learning and learning with distribution shift [38, 54, 79]â€”we give a general iterative polynomial filtering procedure that greatly expands the set of known positive results for learning binary classifiers from contaminated datasets (see Tables 1, 2, and 3). In particular, we obtain the surprising conclusion that all known near-optimal error guarantees for agnostic learning (that can be achieved efficiently) can indeed be extended to the setting of contamination.

Learning with Bounded Contamination.

The earliest works that explored learnability beyond label noise date back more than 30 years ago [89, 69]. Since then, the problem has been studied in the context of learning with malicious [89, 69, 72, 85] and nasty [7, 1, 38, 54, 79] noise. Here we focus on the harshest among these noise models, nasty noise, which we call bounded contamination (defined below), in line with recent work in robust learning (see [28, 79]). In this model, the adversary is allowed to replace an arbitrarily chosen but bounded fraction of a clean dataset with arbitrary labeled datapoints.

Definition 1.1 (Bounded Contamination (BC)).

Let ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D be some distribution over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X, Î·âˆˆ(0,1)ğœ‚01\eta\in(0,1)italic_Î· âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) and f:ğ’³â†’{Â±1}:ğ‘“â†’ğ’³plus-or-minus1f:\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}italic_f : caligraphic_X â†’ { Â± 1 }. We say that a set of samples SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is generated by (ğ’Ÿ,f)ğ’Ÿğ‘“(\mathcal{D},f)( caligraphic_D , italic_f ) with bounded contamination of rate Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· if it is generated as follows for some Mâ‰¥1ğ‘€1M\geq 1italic_M â‰¥ 1.111We use the notation SÂ¯Â¯ğ‘†\bar{S}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG to denote a labeled dataset and distinguish it from its unlabeled counterpart Sğ‘†Sitalic_S.

  1. 1.

    First, a set SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M i.i.d. examples of the form (ğ±,fâ¢(ğ±))ğ±ğ‘“ğ±(\mathbf{x},f(\mathbf{x}))( bold_x , italic_f ( bold_x ) ), where ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿsimilar-toğ±ğ’Ÿ\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D, is drawn.

  2. 2.

    Then, an adversary receives SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, chooses at most Î·â¢Mğœ‚ğ‘€\eta Mitalic_Î· italic_M labeled examples in SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and substitutes them with an equal number of arbitrary labeled examples SÂ¯advsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†adv\bar{S}_{\mathrm{adv}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_adv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to form SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The learner receives a dataset with bounded contamination, and the goal is to output a classifier that enjoys approximately optimal error guarantees on the clean underlying target distribution. It is known that achieving an error better than twice the contamination rate is, in general, impossible [7].

Definition 1.2 (BC-Learning).

An algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is a BC-learner for ğ’âŠ†{ğ’³â†’{Â±1}}ğ’â†’ğ’³plus-or-minus1\mathcal{C}\subseteq\{\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}\}caligraphic_C âŠ† { caligraphic_X â†’ { Â± 1 } } if on input (Ïµ,Î´,SÂ¯inp)italic-Ïµğ›¿subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp(\epsilon,\delta,\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}})( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where Ïµ,Î´âˆˆ(0,1)italic-Ïµğ›¿01\epsilon,\delta\in(0,1)italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ), and SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is generated by (ğ’Ÿ,f)ğ’Ÿğ‘“(\mathcal{D},f)( caligraphic_D , italic_f ) with bounded contamination Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· for some distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X, some fâˆˆğ’ğ‘“ğ’f\in\mathcal{C}italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C and Î·âˆˆ[0,1)ğœ‚01\eta\in[0,1)italic_Î· âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ), the algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A outputs some hypothesis h:ğ’³â†’{Â±1}:â„â†’ğ’³plus-or-minus1h:\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}italic_h : caligraphic_X â†’ { Â± 1 } such that with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´ over the clean examples in SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the randomness of ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A:

â„™ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[fâ¢(ğ±)â‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]â‰¤2â¢Î·+Ïµsubscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿğ‘“ğ±â„ğ±2ğœ‚italic-Ïµ\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[f(\mathbf{x})\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]\leq 2\eta+\epsilonblackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f ( bold_x ) â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ] â‰¤ 2 italic_Î· + italic_Ïµ

The sample complexity of ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is the minimum number of examples required to achieve the above guarantee. Moreover, a distribution-specific BC-learner with respect to some distribution ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ{\mathcal{D}^{*}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X is a BC-learner that is guaranteed to work only when ğ’Ÿ=ğ’Ÿâˆ—ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}={\mathcal{D}^{*}}caligraphic_D = caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Most of the computationally efficient algorithms for learning with bounded contamination provide suboptimal error guarantees and apply only to special concept classes [72, 1, 38]. Nevertheless, a recent line of works inspired by advances in learning with distribution shift [49, 78, 54] has given efficient algorithms with near-optimal guarantees for concept classes that admit sandwiching polynomial approximators [54, 79]. In contrast, for agnostic learning (i.e., adversarial label noise), it is well known that the weaker notion of (non-sandwiching) approximating polynomials is sufficient [68], and there is strong evidence of its necessity [42, 37].

Therefore, the following question naturally arises: does the existence of low-degree approximating polynomials imply efficient learnability even with respect to bounded contamination?

In TheoremÂ 4.2, we give a positive answer to this question, thereby resolving a longstanding gap between the complexity of learning with bounded contamination and with adversarial label noise. This is particularly important as it implies exponential improvements for BC-learning of fundamental concept classes like intersections of halfspaces, monotone functions, and convex sets (see TableÂ 2).

Learning with Heavy Contamination.

Perhaps surprisingly, to our knowledge, binary classification beyond bounded contamination is completely unexplored. In contrast, there is a substantial body of work for learning from datasets where only a small proportion comes from the clean distribution in unsupervised settings [21, 39, 84, 9, 58, 90, 26] and linear regression [84, 66, 26]. These works typically provide list-decodable guarantees (i.e., provide multiple candidate hypotheses only one of which has low error) or require access to a small trusted clean sample. Here, we define a new model for learning binary classifiers with heavy additive contamination that outputs a single hypothesis with a strong error guarantee under the clean distribution. Our model is inspired by recent work on regression (a basic supervised learning task) in additive semi-random models [59, 70].

Definition 1.3 (Heavily Contaminated (HC) Datasets).

Let ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG be some distribution over ğ’³Ã—{Â±1}ğ’³plus-or-minus1\mathcal{X}\times\{\pm 1\}caligraphic_X Ã— { Â± 1 } (we think of ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG as the clean or uncorrupted distribution). We say that a set of samples SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is generated by ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG with Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q-heavy contamination if it is generated as follows for some mâ‰¤Mğ‘šğ‘€m\leq Mitalic_m â‰¤ italic_M with M/mâ‰¤Qğ‘€ğ‘šğ‘„M/m\leq Qitalic_M / italic_m â‰¤ italic_Q.

  1. 1.

    First, a set SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of mğ‘šmitalic_m i.i.d. labeled examples from ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG is drawn.

  2. 2.

    Then, an adversary receives SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and adds Mâˆ’mğ‘€ğ‘šM-mitalic_M - italic_m arbitrary labeled examples to form SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The heavy contamination model only allows the adversary to add points, since removing an arbitrary fraction of the clean samples would correspond to learning with truncation [23, 24, 80], which is beyond the scope of this work (see also RemarkÂ 4.6). Another difference between DefinitionÂ 1.1 and DefinitionÂ 1.3 is that in the HC model, clean labels need not be realized by some function in the given concept class. We instead consider the following quantity

which is the minimum error achievable by the concept class ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C on the whole (contaminated) input dataset SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (including the misclassification errors on the clean samples). The error benchmark we consider is a rescaling of ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalsubscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, proportional to the heavy contamination ratio Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q.

Definition 1.4 (HC-Learning).

An algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is an HC-learner for ğ’âŠ†{ğ’³â†’{Â±1}}ğ’â†’ğ’³plus-or-minus1\mathcal{C}\subseteq\{\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}\}caligraphic_C âŠ† { caligraphic_X â†’ { Â± 1 } } if on input (Ïµ,Î´,Q,SÂ¯inp)italic-Ïµğ›¿ğ‘„subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp(\epsilon,\delta,Q,\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}})( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ , italic_Q , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where Ïµ,Î´âˆˆ(0,1)italic-Ïµğ›¿01\epsilon,\delta\in(0,1)italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ), Qâ‰¥1ğ‘„1Q\geq 1italic_Q â‰¥ 1 and SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q-heavily contaminated set of labeled examples generated by distribution ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG (as described in Definition 1.3), the algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A outputs some hypothesis h:ğ’³â†’{Â±1}:â„â†’ğ’³plus-or-minus1h:\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}italic_h : caligraphic_X â†’ { Â± 1 } such that with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´ over the clean examples in SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the randomness of ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A:

We show that the dependence on Î©â¢(Qâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total)Î©â‹…ğ‘„subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total\Omega(Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}})roman_Î© ( italic_Q â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is, in fact, necessary, even if the clean labels are realized by the learned class ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C. The quantity Qâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalâ‹…ğ‘„subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalQ\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}italic_Q â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equals the number of errors |SÂ¯inp|â‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalâ‹…subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}|\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}| overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the optimal classifier on the input set SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divided by the size of the clean dataset. Our lower bound essentially shows the existence of a contamination strategy that forces any HC learner to pay for all the mistakes of the optimal classifier on SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, even if these are not made on the clean dataset. This is possible as the learner does not know which subset of SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is clean. In the following, we let ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—clean:=minfâˆˆğ’â¢â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯[yâ‰ fâ¢(ğ±)]assignsubscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—cleansubscriptğ‘“ğ’subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦Â¯ğ’Ÿğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ±\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}:=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}% }_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_f ( bold_x ) ] be the optimum error under the clean distribution.

Proposition 1.5 (Informal, see PropositionsÂ B.3 andÂ B.2).

Let ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be any non-trivial class. Then, no HC-learner for ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C can guarantee error better than 12â‹…Qâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalâ‹…12ğ‘„subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total\frac{1}{2}\cdot Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG â‹… italic_Q â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, even when the clean distribution is realizable, i.e., ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—clean=0subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—clean0\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}=0sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0. Moreover, if |ğ’³|<âˆğ’³|\mathcal{X}|<\infty| caligraphic_X | < âˆ, then no HC-learner for ğ’all={Â±1}ğ’³subscriptğ’allsuperscriptplus-or-minus1ğ’³\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{all}}=\{\pm 1\}^{\mathcal{X}}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_all end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { Â± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can guarantee error better than Qâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalâ‹…ğ‘„subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalQ\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}italic_Q â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, even when ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—clean=0subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—clean0\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}=0sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.

Naturally, one might wonder whether the existence of approximating polynomials is sufficient for HC-learning. In TheoremÂ 5.2 we give a negative answer to this question, by providing a lower bound on the sample complexity of HC-learning of monotone functions, which admit low-degree approximators. A recent line of works has used the stronger notion of sandwiching approximators to provide efficient algorithms for various challenging learning tasks [48, 78, 54, 18, 79]. Here, we expand on this paradigm and show that the existence of low-degree sandwiching polynomials implies efficient HC-learning as well (TheoremÂ 4.4).

1.1 Our Results

Learning from Contaminated Datasets.

In TableÂ 1, we present an overview of the upper bounds we obtain as applications of our main theorems on learning with contamination (TheoremsÂ 4.2 andÂ 4.4). For comparison, we also provide the corresponding results on learning with label noise from prior work. For the case of bounded contamination, and for constant error and confidence parameters (Ïµ,Î´italic-Ïµğ›¿\epsilon,\deltaitalic_Ïµ , italic_Î´), our results match the best known bounds for learning with label noise, since in both cases, the existence of low-degree polynomial approximators is sufficient. See TablesÂ 2 andÂ 3 for further details.

All of our results work in the distribution-specific setting. Distributional assumptions are unavoidable, as there is strong evidence that distribution-free learning of even the simplest classes (e.g., linear classifiers) in the presence of noise is computationally hard [44, 22]. Although we present our results for specific standard target marginal distributions, our results hold for any hypercontractive (DefinitionÂ 3.1) marginal ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that can be sampled efficiently, as long as the degree of approximation (resp.Â sandwiching for HC-learning) of the learned class is low under ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Hypercontractive distributions are an extremely wide class of probability distributions, which includes Gaussians, all log-concave distributions over â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\mathbb{R}}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as well as product distributions over {Â±1}dsuperscriptplus-or-minus1ğ‘‘\{\pm 1\}^{d}{ Â± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. See AppendixÂ C for an overview of relevant results in approximation theory.

On the lower bound side, we show that learning monotone functions with heavy contamination requires exponentially many samples, thereby separating bounded and heavy contamination. For a more thorough discussion on lower bounds for learning with contamination, see SectionÂ 5.222We note that although learning with bounded contamination is clearly more challenging than learning with adversarial label noise, many of the known lower bounds for agnostic learning do not transfer directly to BC-learning as formalized in DefinitionÂ 1.1 for technical reasons. See SectionÂ 5 for a way to circumvent this.

Testable Learning.

A recent line of works in learning theory has focused on providing learning algorithms that can verify their distributional assumptions [83, 48, 50, 33, 51, 87, 54]. These algorithms are allowed to either accept and output a classifier with certified optimal performance, or detect a violation of their target distributional assumptions and reject. Here, we provide improved results for a tolerant version of this problem where the algorithm has to accept even if the input distribution is close to the target distribution. Tolerant testable learning was first studied in [54] (see DefinitionÂ 4.7).

In TheoremÂ 4.8, we show that the existence of low-degree sandwiching polynomials implies efficient tolerant testable learning. Previously, [54] required the existence of low-degree â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-sandwiching polynomials, which is a stronger assumption. Moreover, all of the previous results in testable learningâ€”even the non-tolerant variantsâ€”required that the sandwiching polynomials have bounded coefficients. Here, we do not impose such a requirement and obtain the first testable learning results for functions of halfspaces with respect to any fixed log-concave distribution. All prior work either gave worse error guarantees [51, 50], or required target marginals with strictly sub-exponential tails [48]. See SectionÂ 4.3 for more details.

1.2 Our Techniques

Iterative Polynomial Filtering.

All of our results use the same iterative polynomial filtering algorithm of TheoremÂ 3.2 with appropriate hyperparameter choices. The algorithm receives a set Sinpsubscriptğ‘†inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of data points and filters it, outputting a subset Sfiltsubscriptğ‘†filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of Sinpsubscriptğ‘†inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that satisfies the following two conditions. First, any low-degree polynomial pğ‘pitalic_p whose absolute expectation ğ”¼[|pâ¢(ğ±)|]ğ”¼ğ‘ğ±\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]blackboard_E [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] over the pre-specified target distribution ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is small, will also have bounded average over Sfiltsubscriptğ‘†filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e. 1|Sfilt|â¢âˆ‘ğ±âˆˆSfiltpâ¢(ğ±)1subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ±subscriptğ‘†filtğ‘ğ±\frac{1}{|S_{\mathrm{filt}}|}\sum_{\mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{filt}}}p(\mathbf{x})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆˆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_x ) is small. Second, if Sinpsubscriptğ‘†inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains a set of points Sğ‘†Sitalic_S that were initially generated independently by ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then only a limited number of points from Sğ‘†Sitalic_S can be removed by the filtering (the allowed number of removed points is controlled by an appropriate hyperparameter).

Our algorithm is a refined version of bounded-degree outlier removal procedures from robust learning and learning with distribution shift [38, 29, 54, 79]. The general principle behind these algorithms is that one can iteratively find polynomials that violate the desired condition over the input set and use them to filter the input points. In particular, the algorithm removes the points that give such polynomials values larger than a threshold. By choosing this threshold appropriately, one can control the proportion of removed points that lie in the clean set Sğ‘†Sitalic_S in each step.

Prior work only gave guarantees for squared polynomials [38, 54] and for non-negative polynomials [79]. Here, we give a filtering algorithm that preserves the expectation of any polynomial, as long as its absolute expectation is small with respect to the target distribution. This is crucial for our application in BC-learning. Moreover, our filtering procedure works for any hypercontractive target distribution ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is also true for [38, 54] but not for [79], which only works for the uniform distribution over the hypercube.

Learning with Bounded Contamination.

Our algorithm follows a two-phase approach: (1) Run our outlier-removal algorithm, and obtain a filtered subset Sfiltsubscriptğ‘†filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. (2) Following an approach similar to [68], construct a predictor based on the polynomial p^^ğ‘\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG with smallest â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT error on Sfiltsubscriptğ‘†filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We now give a sketch of the analysis of this algorithm and explain how an error of Oâ¢(Î·+Ïµ)ğ‘‚ğœ‚italic-ÏµO(\eta+\epsilon)italic_O ( italic_Î· + italic_Ïµ ) can be guaranteed. (The optimal dependence of 2â¢Î·+Ïµ2ğœ‚italic-Ïµ2\eta+\epsilon2 italic_Î· + italic_Ïµ is obtained by carefully refining the analysis below.)

What would happen if we ran the phase (2) without filtering the dataset beforehand? As shown in [68], this approach works in the agnostic setting, i.e. when an adversary can corrupt only the labels but not the examples. A key observation in [68] is that if pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximating polynomial for the ground truth fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then after Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· fraction of data labels are corrupted, the polynomial pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will have an â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-error of only at most Î·+Ïµğœ‚italic-Ïµ\eta+\epsilonitalic_Î· + italic_Ïµ. However, in the more challenging setting of learning with contamination over â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\mathbb{R}}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, even a single corrupted data-point can cause the â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-error of pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be arbitrarily large. The reason is that any non-zero polynomial over â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\mathbb{R}}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will be arbitrarily large in absolute value when evaluated at inputs ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}bold_x far enough from the origin.

Hence, the first phase of our algorithm aims to filter out such bad input datapoints. The following basic observation is key to our approach: if pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an Ïµ4superscriptitalic-Ïµ4\epsilon^{4}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-approximator in â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm for a {Â±1}plus-or-minus1\{\pm 1\}{ Â± 1 }-valued function fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then the average ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâˆ—[|(pâˆ—â¢(ğ±))2âˆ’1|]subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±superscriptğ’Ÿsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ±21\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[|(p^{*}(\mathbf{x})% )^{2}-1|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 | ] is at most Oâ¢(Ïµ2)ğ‘‚superscriptitalic-Ïµ2O(\epsilon^{2})italic_O ( italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). This observation, together with our filtering guarantee, ensures that the average ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sfilt[(pâˆ—â¢(ğ±))2âˆ’1]subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ±21\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}}[(p^{*}(\mathbf{x% }))^{2}-1]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 ] is likewise bounded by Oâ¢(Ïµ)ğ‘‚italic-ÏµO(\epsilon)italic_O ( italic_Ïµ ) while removing almost exclusively outliers.

Yet, the set Sfiltsubscriptğ‘†filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT might still contain many outliers. We show that the condition ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sfilt[(pâˆ—â¢(ğ±))2âˆ’1]â‰¤Oâ¢(Ïµ)subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ±21ğ‘‚italic-Ïµ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}}[(p^{*}(\mathbf{x% }))^{2}-1]\leq O(\epsilon)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 ] â‰¤ italic_O ( italic_Ïµ ) implies that the remaining outliers are not dangerous when it comes to phase (2) of our algorithm. Indeed, this condition tells us that the number of remaining outliers ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}bold_x in Sfiltsubscriptğ‘†filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with |pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|>Ï„superscriptğ‘ğ±ğœ|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau| italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ is at most Oâ¢(|Sfilt|â¢Ïµ/Ï„2)ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘†filtitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğœ2O({|S_{\mathrm{filt}}|\epsilon}/{\tau^{2}})italic_O ( | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïµ / italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Taking Ï„=2ğœ2\tau=2italic_Ï„ = 2, we see that the total contribution to the â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT error of pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on Sfiltsubscriptğ‘†filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of outliers ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}bold_x with |pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|>2superscriptğ‘ğ±2|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>2| italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > 2 is Oâ¢(Ïµ)ğ‘‚italic-ÏµO(\epsilon)italic_O ( italic_Ïµ ). The remaining outliers contribute at most Oâ¢(Î·)ğ‘‚ğœ‚O(\eta)italic_O ( italic_Î· ) to this error, since there are at most Oâ¢(Î·)ğ‘‚ğœ‚O(\eta)italic_O ( italic_Î· ) of such outliers and each satisfies |pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|â‰¤2superscriptğ‘ğ±2|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|\leq 2| italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | â‰¤ 2.

Overall, we see that the â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT error of pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on Sfiltsubscriptğ‘†filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is at most Oâ¢(Î·+Ïµ)ğ‘‚ğœ‚italic-ÏµO(\eta+\epsilon)italic_O ( italic_Î· + italic_Ïµ ), and therefore the polynomial p^^ğ‘\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG found in phase 2 of our algorithm will also have an â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT error of at most Oâ¢(Î·+Ïµ)ğ‘‚ğœ‚italic-ÏµO(\eta+\epsilon)italic_O ( italic_Î· + italic_Ïµ ) on Sfiltsubscriptğ‘†filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since phase (1) only removed at most Oâ¢(Ïµ)ğ‘‚italic-ÏµO(\epsilon)italic_O ( italic_Ïµ ) clean datapoints, we conclude that the â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT error of p^^ğ‘\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG on the clean dataset Sclnsubscriptğ‘†clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is likewise Oâ¢(Î·+Ïµ)ğ‘‚ğœ‚italic-ÏµO(\eta+\epsilon)italic_O ( italic_Î· + italic_Ïµ ), which we use to bound the out-of-distribution error of p^^ğ‘\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG.

Learning with Heavy Contamination.

Our heavy contamination algorithm follows the same structure as the one for bounded contamination: we first run the iterative filtering algorithm and then run â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT polynomial regression on the filtered dataset. This time, however, we choose the hyperparameters of the iterative filtering algorithm so that the proportion of removed points that are clean is inversely proportional to the heavy contamination ratio Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q. In this way, we make sure to remove only a small fraction of the clean points.

To conclude the proof, we use the notion of sandwiching polynomials. In particular, if fâˆ—âˆˆğ’superscriptğ‘“ğ’f^{*}\in\mathcal{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_C is the optimum classifier on the input dataset, and pup,pdownsubscriptğ‘upsubscriptğ‘downp_{\mathrm{up}},p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are two low-degree polynomials such that (1) pupâ¢(ğ±)â‰¥fâˆ—â¢(ğ±)â‰¥pdownâ¢(ğ±)subscriptğ‘upğ±superscriptğ‘“ğ±subscriptğ‘downğ±p_{\mathrm{up}}(\mathbf{x})\geq f^{*}(\mathbf{x})\geq p_{\mathrm{down}}(% \mathbf{x})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) â‰¥ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) â‰¥ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) for all ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}bold_x and (2) ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâˆ—[pupâ¢(ğ±)âˆ’pdownâ¢(ğ±)]â‰¤Oâ¢(Ïµ2/Q)subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±superscriptğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘upğ±subscriptğ‘downğ±ğ‘‚superscriptitalic-Ïµ2ğ‘„\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[p_{\mathrm{up}}(% \mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})]\leq O(\epsilon^{2}/Q)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] â‰¤ italic_O ( italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Q ), then the filtering process guarantees that ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sfilt[pupâ¢(ğ±)âˆ’pdownâ¢(ğ±)]subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘upğ±subscriptğ‘downğ±\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}}[p_{\mathrm{up}}(% \mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] scales proportionally to Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ. Overall, this implies that pdownsubscriptğ‘downp_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has low â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-error under Sfiltsubscriptğ‘†filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and that â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-polynomial regression achieves near-optimal error guarantees.

1.3 Related Work

Supervised Learning with Noise.

The majority of existing works on robust supervised learning focus on label noise. In order to obtain efficient algorithms, it is standard and often necessary to make assumptions on the marginal distribution [22, 27, 35], although there have been recent attempts to relax those assumptions [17]. Even under common distributional assumptions, the best possible error guarantees often require exponential dependence on the excess error parameter Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ [42, 37]. A line of works was focused on providing faster learning algorithms for some classes at the expense of relaxed error guarantees [1, 38, 41] or under restricted noise models [40, 32]. We consider the more challenging scenario of learning with contamination, where there is noise on both the input examples and their labels. Before this work, efficient algorithms for learning with bounded contamination up to optimal error were known only for classes with low sandwiching degree [54, 79], and nothing was known about classification under heavy contamination.

Semi-Random Models.

Our DefinitionÂ 1.3 is inspired by semi-random models, which lie between the average and worst case settings [13, 45]. In particular, it resembles an instantiation of the semi-random model framework known as a monotone adversary, which breaks a statistical assumption used by a learning algorithm (e.g., i.i.d.Â draws from a known distribution) by providing additional data. Our approach is inspired by recent algorithms for supervised regression problems, e.g., solving linear systems, sparse recovery, or matrix completion [16, 70, 59, 71], that are tolerant to monotone adversaries. These algorithms also use reweightings that come with certificates of success. However, a major qualitative difference between the aforementioned works and ours is that our DefinitionÂ 1.3 does not require that the adversary uses labels consistent with a â€œclean hypothesis.â€ Instead, our algorithms can tolerate label noise (alongside covariate noise) and achieve the information-theoretically optimal clean error under such a model (PropositionÂ 1.5).

Testable Learning.

In recent years, a number of works has focused on verifying the assumptions of learning algorithms. Testable learning was introduced by [83] in the context of verifying the distributional assumptions of agnostic learners and there are several subsequent works on this setting [48, 51, 33, 50, 34, 87]. This paradigm has since been expanded to testing for distribution shifts that may harm the performance of supervised learning algorithms [78, 77, 18, 19], or even testing noise assumptions [52]. Here, we study a tolerant version of testable agnostic learning that was first studied by [54], and provide the first guarantees for halfspaces with respect to any fixed log-concave measure.

Learning with heavy contamination can be thought of as a search version of testable learning. More specifically, in testable learning the goal is to decide whether the input dataset is structured enough so that a near-optimal hypothesis can be found efficiently, while in HC-learning the goal is to find a subset of the input that is structured enough. An analogous connection was observed in [54] between TDS learning [78] and PQ learning [49] in the context of learning under distribution shift. There, the goal was to either decide whether the (unlabeled) test examples come from a distribution that is similar to the one the learner has trained on (TDS), or find a subset of the test examples where the learner is confident in its predictions (PQ). See RemarkÂ 4.5.

2 Notation

We consider a dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional feature space ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X which will either be â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\mathbb{R}}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or the hypercube {Â±1}dsuperscriptplus-or-minus1ğ‘‘\{\pm 1\}^{d}{ Â± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.
