The degree of pğ‘pitalic_p is equal to the maximum â€–Î±â€–1subscriptnormğ›¼1\|\alpha\|_{1}âˆ¥ italic_Î± âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that cpâ¢(Î±)â‰ 0subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ›¼0c_{p}(\alpha)\neq 0italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î± ) â‰  0. Over {Â±1}dsuperscriptplus-or-minus1ğ‘‘\{\pm 1\}^{d}{ Â± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we use the multilinear expansion pâ¢(ğ±)=âˆ‘â„âŠ†[d]cpâ¢(â„)â¢ğ±â„ğ‘ğ±subscriptâ„delimited-[]ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘â„superscriptğ±â„p(\mathbf{x})=\sum_{\mathcal{I}\subseteq[d]}c_{p}(\mathcal{I})\mathbf{x}^{% \mathcal{I}}italic_p ( bold_x ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I âŠ† [ italic_d ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_I ) bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ğ±â„=âˆiâˆˆâ„xisuperscriptğ±â„subscriptproductğ‘–â„subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\mathbf{x}^{\mathcal{I}}=\prod_{i\in\mathcal{I}}x_{i}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ caligraphic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In both cases, we call ğœpsubscriptğœğ‘\mathbf{c}_{p}bold_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the vector of coefficients. We consider sets of points Sğ‘†Sitalic_S to contain examples that are separate instances of the correponding elements of ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. We denote with SÂ¯Â¯ğ‘†\bar{S}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG the corresponding labeled set of examples. We use ğ±âˆ¼Ssimilar-toğ±ğ‘†\mathbf{x}\sim Sbold_x âˆ¼ italic_S to say that ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}bold_x is drawn uniformly from Sğ‘†Sitalic_S. For a labeled distribution ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG over ğ’³Ã—{Â±1}ğ’³plus-or-minus1\mathcal{X}\times\{\pm 1\}caligraphic_X Ã— { Â± 1 }, ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D is the marginal on ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. In the following the distribution-specific algorithms have sample access to the unlabeled target distribution ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We use ğ’©d=ğ’©â¢(0,ğˆd)subscriptğ’©ğ‘‘ğ’©0subscriptğˆğ‘‘\mathcal{N}_{d}=\mathcal{N}(0,\mathbf{I}_{d})caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_N ( 0 , bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to denote the standard dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional Gaussian and Unifd=Unifâ¢{Â±1}dsubscriptUnifğ‘‘Unifsuperscriptplus-or-minus1ğ‘‘\mathrm{Unif}_{d}=\mathrm{Unif}\{\pm 1\}^{d}roman_Unif start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Unif { Â± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for the uniform over the dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional hypercube.

3 Iterative Polynomial Filtering

We first define hypercontractivity, which is a crucial assumption for our filtering procedure.

Definition 3.1 (Hypercontractivity).

We say that a distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X is Ağ´{A}italic_A-hypercontractive with respect to polynomials for some Aâ‰¥1ğ´1{A}\geq 1italic_A â‰¥ 1 if for any polynomial pğ‘pitalic_p over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X and any tâ‰¥2ğ‘¡2t\geq 2italic_t â‰¥ 2 we have

  1. 1.

    ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[|p(ğ±)|t]â‰¤(At)â„“â¢t(ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[|p(ğ±)|])t,Â whereÂ â„“=deg(p)\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|^{t}]% \leq({A}t)^{\ell t}\bigr{(}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{% D}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]\bigr{)}^{t}\,,\text{ where }\ell=\deg(p)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ ( italic_A italic_t ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , where roman_â„“ = roman_deg ( italic_p )

  2. 2.

    The absolute value of any degree-1111 monomial has finite expectation under ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D.

Our main algorithmic tool is the following theorem, which gives a way to filter an arbitrary set of examples in order to preserve the expectations of polynomials whose expected absolute value under some hypercontractive target distribution is small.

Theorem 3.2 (Iterative Filtering).

Let ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a Ağ´{A}italic_A-hypercontractive distribution over a dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional space ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. Consider parameters Ïµ,Î´âˆˆ(0,1)italic-Ïµğ›¿01\epsilon,\delta\in(0,1)italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) and R,â„“,mâ‰¥1ğ‘…â„“ğ‘š1R,\ell,m\geq 1italic_R , roman_â„“ , italic_m â‰¥ 1, and let Sinpsubscriptğ‘†inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be an arbitrary set of examples in ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X and Srefsubscriptğ‘†refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT a set of mrefsubscriptğ‘šrefm_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT i.i.d.Â examples from ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For a sufficiently large universal constant Câ‰¥1ğ¶1C\geq 1italic_C â‰¥ 1, if mrefâ‰¥R2â¢(Câ¢Aâ¢d)2â¢â„“Ïµ3â¢(logâ¡1Î´)4â¢â„“+1subscriptğ‘šrefsuperscriptğ‘…2superscriptğ¶ğ´ğ‘‘2â„“superscriptitalic-Ïµ3superscript1ğ›¿4â„“1m_{\mathrm{ref}}\geq\frac{R^{2}(CAd)^{2\ell}}{\epsilon^{3}}(\log\frac{1}{% \delta})^{4\ell+1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ divide start_ARG italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then AlgorithmÂ 1 on input (Sinp,Sref,m,â„“,R,Ïµ)subscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘†refğ‘šâ„“ğ‘…italic-Ïµ(S_{\mathrm{inp}},S_{\mathrm{ref}},m,\ell,R,\epsilon)( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m , roman_â„“ , italic_R , italic_Ïµ ) runs in time polyâ¡(|Sinp|,mref,(d+1)â„“)polysubscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘šrefsuperscriptğ‘‘1â„“\operatorname{poly}(|S_{\mathrm{inp}}|,m_{\mathrm{ref}},(d+1)^{\ell})roman_poly ( | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | , italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and outputs SfiltâŠ†Sinpsubscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘†inpS_{\mathrm{filt}}\subseteq S_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that the following hold:

  1. 1.

    Let Sclnsubscriptğ‘†clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be any set of mğ‘šmitalic_m i.i.d. examples from ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where mâ‰¥Câ¢R2â¢(2â¢Aâ¢(d+1))2â¢â„“Ïµ3â¢logâ¡1Î´ğ‘šğ¶superscriptğ‘…2superscript2ğ´ğ‘‘12â„“superscriptitalic-Ïµ31ğ›¿m\geq CR^{2}\frac{(2A(d+1))^{2\ell}}{\epsilon^{3}}\log\frac{1}{\delta}italic_m â‰¥ italic_C italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG ( 2 italic_A ( italic_d + 1 ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG. Suppose that Sinpsubscriptğ‘†inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is formed by first removing an arbitrary fraction of points in Sclnsubscriptğ‘†clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and then adding any number of arbitrary points. Then, the algorithm removes a relatively small number of the examples in Sclnsubscriptğ‘†clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that appear in Sinpsubscriptğ‘†inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

    |(Sclnâˆ©Sinp)âˆ–Sfilt|â‰¤1Râ‹…|Sinpâˆ–Sfilt|+Ïµâ¢m2,Â with probability at leastÂ â¢1âˆ’Î´â¢Â overÂ â¢Scln,Srefsubscriptğ‘†clnsubscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘†filtâ‹…1ğ‘…subscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘†filtitalic-Ïµğ‘š2Â with probability at leastÂ 1ğ›¿Â overÂ subscriptğ‘†clnsubscriptğ‘†ref|(S_{\mathrm{cln}}\cap S_{\mathrm{inp}})\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|\leq\frac{% 1}{R}\cdot|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|+\frac{\epsilon m}{2}\,% ,\text{ with probability at least }1-\delta\text{ over }S_{\mathrm{cln}},S_{% \mathrm{ref}}| ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_R end_ARG â‹… | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG , with probability at least 1 - italic_Î´ over italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
  2. 2.

    For any polynomial pğ‘pitalic_p of degree at most â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“, and ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâˆ—[|pâ¢(ğ±)|]â‰¤Ïµ4â¢Rsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ğ±italic-Ïµ4ğ‘…\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]% \leq\frac{\epsilon}{4R}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 4 italic_R end_ARG we have:

    âˆ‘ğ±âˆˆSfiltpâ¢(ğ±)â‰¤Ïµâ¢m,Â with probability at leastÂ â¢1âˆ’Î´â¢Â overÂ â¢Srefsubscriptğ±subscriptğ‘†filtğ‘ğ±italic-Ïµğ‘šÂ with probability at leastÂ 1ğ›¿Â overÂ subscriptğ‘†ref\sum_{\mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{filt}}}p(\mathbf{x})\leq\epsilon m\,,\text{ % with probability at least }1-\delta\text{ over }S_{\mathrm{ref}}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆˆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_x ) â‰¤ italic_Ïµ italic_m , with probability at least 1 - italic_Î´ over italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

The algorithm iteratively removes the points that give large values to polynomials that do not satisfy the stopping criterion of line 1. The hyperparameter Rğ‘…Ritalic_R determines how selective the filtering is: larger values of Rğ‘…Ritalic_R imply that less points will be removed in each iteration, and the proportion of removed points that are clean is smaller. The price one has to pay for larger choices of Rğ‘…Ritalic_R is that the guarantee of part 2 holds for polynomials with smaller absolute expectation under the target distribution.

Our algorithm requires access to a set of reference samples from the target distribution ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and uses them to restrict its attention to polynomials with the desired properties under ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The stopping criterion ensures that upon completion all of these polynomials will have bounded expectations under the empirical distribution over the filtered set. The bound depends on the hyperparameters Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ (target error) and mğ‘šmitalic_m (effective size), but not on the degree â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ of the polynomials considered.

We now give the proof of our main technical tool, TheoremÂ 3.2. The proof follows the approach of [79], but has a number of technical differences. In particular, the algorithm of [79] only gives guarantees for non-negative polynomials and works with respect to the uniform distribution on the hypercube. Here, we preserve the expectation of any polynomial, with respect to any target hypercontractive distribution that can be sampled efficiently.

Proof of TheoremÂ 3.2.

We first observe that the family ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P of polynomials pğ‘pitalic_p of degree at most â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ for which ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sref[|pâ¢(ğ±)|]â‰¤Î³subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†refğ‘ğ±ğ›¾\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]\leq\gammablackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] â‰¤ italic_Î³ and ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sref[(pâ¢(ğ±))2]â‰¤Î²subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†refsuperscriptğ‘ğ±2ğ›½\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{% 2}]\leq\betablackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ italic_Î² can be described by Oâ¢(mref)ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘šrefO(m_{\mathrm{ref}})italic_O ( italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) linear constraints plus one convex quadratic constraint over the coefficient vectors whose dimension is (d+1)â„“superscriptğ‘‘1â„“(d+1)^{\ell}( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, lines 1 and 5 can be implemented as convex programs in time polyâ¡(|Sinp|,mref,(d+1)â„“)polysubscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘šrefsuperscriptğ‘‘1â„“\operatorname{poly}(|S_{\mathrm{inp}}|,m_{\mathrm{ref}},(d+1)^{\ell})roman_poly ( | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | , italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Lines 1 and 1 can be implemented with a single pass of the input points.

We first prove the following claim, which ensures that lines 1 and 1 are well defined.

Claim.

When Î»âˆ—>Ïµsuperscriptğœ†italic-Ïµ\lambda^{*}>\epsilonitalic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > italic_Ïµ, there exists Ï„âˆ—â‰¥0superscriptğœ0\tau^{*}\geq 0italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 that satisfies the guarantees of line 1.

Proof.

Suppose, for contradiction, that for any Ï„â‰¥0ğœ0\tau\geq 0italic_Ï„ â‰¥ 0 we have

|S|mâ¢â„™ğ±âˆ¼S[|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|>Ï„]<Râ‹…â„™ğ±âˆ¼Sref[|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|>Ï„]+Î”ğ‘†ğ‘šsubscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘†superscriptğ‘ğ±ğœâ‹…ğ‘…subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†refsuperscriptğ‘ğ±ğœÎ”\frac{|S|}{m}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|% >\tau]<R\cdot\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[|p^{% *}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau]+\Deltadivide start_ARG | italic_S | end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ ] < italic_R â‹… blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ ] + roman_Î”

We may now integrate both sides of the inequality over Ï„âˆˆ[0,B]ğœ0ğµ\tau\in[0,B]italic_Ï„ âˆˆ [ 0 , italic_B ], since it holds for all Ï„â‰¥0ğœ0\tau\geq 0italic_Ï„ â‰¥ 0. Note that |pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|â‰¥0superscriptğ‘ğ±0|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|\geq 0| italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | â‰¥ 0 for all ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}bold_x and, therefore, the following are true

ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼S[|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|]subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ‘†superscriptğ‘ğ±\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] =âˆ«Ï„=0âˆâ„™ğ±âˆ¼S[|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|>Ï„]â¢ğ‘‘Ï„=âˆ«Ï„=0Bâ„™ğ±âˆ¼S[|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|>Ï„]â¢ğ‘‘Ï„absentsuperscriptsubscriptğœ0subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘†superscriptğ‘ğ±ğœdifferential-dğœsuperscriptsubscriptğœ0ğµsubscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘†superscriptğ‘ğ±ğœdifferential-dğœ\displaystyle=\int_{\tau=0}^{\infty}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S% }[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau]\;d\tau=\int_{\tau=0}^{B}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}% _{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau]\;d\tau= âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ ] italic_d italic_Ï„ = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ ] italic_d italic_Ï„ (3.1)
ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sref[|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|]subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†refsuperscriptğ‘ğ±\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[|p^{% *}(\mathbf{x})|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] =âˆ«Ï„=0âˆâ„™ğ±âˆ¼Sref[|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|>Ï„]â¢ğ‘‘Ï„â‰¥âˆ«Ï„=0Bâ„™ğ±âˆ¼Sref[|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|>Ï„]â¢ğ‘‘Ï„absentsuperscriptsubscriptğœ0subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†refsuperscriptğ‘ğ±ğœdifferential-dğœsuperscriptsubscriptğœ0ğµsubscriptâ„™similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†refsuperscriptğ‘ğ±ğœdifferential-dğœ\displaystyle=\int_{\tau=0}^{\infty}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S% _{\mathrm{ref}}}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau]\;d\tau\geq\int_{\tau=0}^{B}% \operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x}% )|>\tau]\;d\tau= âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ ] italic_d italic_Ï„ â‰¥ âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ ] italic_d italic_Ï„ (3.2)

The second equality in Eq.Â (3.1) follows from the fact that for any pâˆ—âˆˆğ’«superscriptğ‘ğ’«p^{*}\in\mathcal{P}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_P, Sğ‘†Sitalic_S contains only points such that pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)âˆˆ[âˆ’B,B]superscriptğ‘ğ±ğµğµp^{*}(\mathbf{x})\in[-B,B]italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) âˆˆ [ - italic_B , italic_B ], due to line 1. The inequality in Eq.Â (3.2) follows from the fact that the integrated function is non-negative. Overall, we obtain the following inequality

Î»âˆ—=|S|mâ¢ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼S[pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)]â‰¤|S|mâ¢ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼S[|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|]<Râ‹…ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sref[|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|]+Î”â¢Bâ‰¤Ïµ,superscriptğœ†ğ‘†ğ‘šsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ‘†superscriptğ‘ğ±ğ‘†ğ‘šsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ‘†superscriptğ‘ğ±â‹…ğ‘…subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†refsuperscriptğ‘ğ±Î”ğµitalic-Ïµ\lambda^{*}=\frac{|S|}{m}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[p^{*}(% \mathbf{x})]\leq\frac{|S|}{m}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[|p^% {*}(\mathbf{x})|]<R\cdot\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{% ref}}}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|]+\Delta B\leq\epsilon\,,italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG | italic_S | end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG | italic_S | end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] < italic_R â‹… blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] + roman_Î” italic_B â‰¤ italic_Ïµ ,

where the last inequality follows from the fact that pâˆ—âˆˆğ’«superscriptğ‘ğ’«p^{*}\in\mathcal{P}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_P and, hence, ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sref[|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|]â‰¤Ïµ2â¢Rsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†refsuperscriptğ‘ğ±italic-Ïµ2ğ‘…\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x}% )|]\leq\frac{\epsilon}{2R}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_R end_ARG and Î”=Ïµ2â¢BÎ”italic-Ïµ2ğµ\Delta=\frac{\epsilon}{2B}roman_Î” = divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_B end_ARG. We have reached contradiction, because we showed that Î»âˆ—â‰¤Ïµsuperscriptğœ†italic-Ïµ\lambda^{*}\leq\epsilonitalic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ. âˆ

Note that due to the claim above, we have {ğ±âˆˆS:|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|>Ï„âˆ—}â‰ âˆ…conditional-setğ±ğ‘†superscriptğ‘ğ±superscriptğœ\{\mathbf{x}\in S:|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau^{*}\}\neq\emptyset{ bold_x âˆˆ italic_S : | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } â‰  âˆ…. This means that at each iteration we remove at least one point from the input dataset and, therefore, we do not need more than M=|Sinp|ğ‘€subscriptğ‘†inpM=|S_{\mathrm{inp}}|italic_M = | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | iterations. The following claim ensures that we only remove a small fraction of clean points from Sinpsubscriptğ‘†inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Claim.

With probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´ over Sclnsubscriptğ‘†clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Srefsubscriptğ‘†refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have

|(Sclnâˆ©Sinp)âˆ–Sfilt|â‰¤Ïµâ¢m2+1Râ‹…|Sinpâˆ–Sfilt|subscriptğ‘†clnsubscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘†filtitalic-Ïµğ‘š2â‹…1ğ‘…subscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘†filt|(S_{\mathrm{cln}}\cap S_{\mathrm{inp}})\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|\leq\frac{% \epsilon m}{2}+\frac{1}{R}\cdot|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|| ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_R end_ARG â‹… | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |
Proof.

We will show that with high probability over the clean and reference datasets, the number of removed points from Sclnsubscriptğ‘†clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is small. First, we account for the initial filtering of line 1. In this step, we remove points ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}bold_x from Sinpsubscriptğ‘†inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that give large absolute values to polynomials in ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P, i.e., polynomials who, in particular, have bounded second norms over Srefsubscriptğ‘†refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Due to LemmaÂ A.2 and since mrefâ‰¥(Câ¢Aâ¢d)2â¢â„“â¢(logâ¡1Î´)4â¢â„“+1subscriptğ‘šrefsuperscriptğ¶ğ´ğ‘‘2â„“superscript1ğ›¿4â„“1m_{\mathrm{ref}}\geq(CAd)^{2\ell}(\log\frac{1}{\delta})^{4\ell+1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ ( italic_C italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the probability that some ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}bold_x drawn from ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D gives |pâ¢(ğ±)|>Bğ‘ğ±ğµ|p(\mathbf{x})|>B| italic_p ( bold_x ) | > italic_B for some pâˆˆğ’«ğ‘ğ’«p\in\mathcal{P}italic_p âˆˆ caligraphic_P is at most Ïµ/4italic-Ïµ4\epsilon/4italic_Ïµ / 4. Therefore, the total number of points removed from Sclnsubscriptğ‘†clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in this step follows the binomial distribution with mğ‘šmitalic_m number of trials and probability of success at most Ïµ/4italic-Ïµ4\epsilon/4italic_Ïµ / 4. By a standard Chernoff bound, and since mâ‰¥CÏµâ¢logâ¡(1/Î´)ğ‘šğ¶italic-Ïµ1ğ›¿m\geq\frac{C}{\epsilon}\log(1/\delta)italic_m â‰¥ divide start_ARG italic_C end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG roman_log ( 1 / italic_Î´ ), with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´/21ğ›¿21-\delta/21 - italic_Î´ / 2 we have

|{ğ±âˆˆScln:|pâ¢(ğ±)|>Bâ¢Â for someÂ â¢pâˆˆğ’«}|â‰¤Ïµâ¢m/2conditional-setğ±subscriptğ‘†clnğ‘ğ±ğµÂ for someÂ ğ‘ğ’«italic-Ïµğ‘š2|\{\mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{cln}}:|p(\mathbf{x})|>B\text{ for some }p\in% \mathcal{P}\}|\leq\epsilon m/2| { bold_x âˆˆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : | italic_p ( bold_x ) | > italic_B for some italic_p âˆˆ caligraphic_P } | â‰¤ italic_Ïµ italic_m / 2 (3.3)

It remains to account for the points removed in line 1. The removed points are always of the form {ğ±âˆˆS:|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|>Ï„âˆ—}conditional-setğ±ğ‘†superscriptğ‘ğ±superscriptğœ\{\mathbf{x}\in S:|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau^{*}\}{ bold_x âˆˆ italic_S : | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } for some pâˆ—âˆˆğ’«superscriptğ‘ğ’«p^{*}\in\mathcal{P}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_P. Moreover, according to line 1, we have

1mâ¢âˆ‘ğ±âˆˆSğŸ™â¡{|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|>Ï„âˆ—}â‰¥Râ‹…â„™ğ±âˆ¼Sref[|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|>Ï„âˆ—]+Î”1ğ‘šsubscriptğ±ğ‘†1superscriptğ‘ğ±superscriptğœâ‹…ğ‘…subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†refsuperscriptğ‘ğ±superscriptğœÎ”\frac{1}{m}\sum_{\mathbf{x}\in S}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{|p^{*}(\mathbf{x}% )|>\tau^{*}\}\geq R\cdot\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{% ref}}}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau^{*}]+\Deltadivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆˆ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } â‰¥ italic_R â‹… blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] + roman_Î”

Since m,mrefâ‰¥Câ€²â¢(d+1)â„“+logâ¡(1/Î´)(Î”/R)2ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘šrefsuperscriptğ¶â€²superscriptğ‘‘1â„“1ğ›¿superscriptÎ”ğ‘…2m,m_{\mathrm{ref}}\geq C^{\prime}\frac{(d+1)^{\ell}+\log(1/\delta)}{(\Delta/R)% ^{2}}italic_m , italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_log ( 1 / italic_Î´ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( roman_Î” / italic_R ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG for some sufficiently large universal constant Câ€²â‰¥1superscriptğ¶â€²1C^{\prime}\geq 1italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ 1 and the VC dimension of the class of polynomial threshold functions of degree â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ is at most (d+1)â„“superscriptğ‘‘1â„“(d+1)^{\ell}( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have that with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´/21ğ›¿21-\delta/21 - italic_Î´ / 2 over Sclnsubscriptğ‘†clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Srefsubscriptğ‘†refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the following holds for all polynomials pğ‘pitalic_p of degree at most â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ and all Ï„â‰¥0ğœ0\tau\geq 0italic_Ï„ â‰¥ 0

Râ‹…â„™ğ±âˆ¼Scln[|pâ¢(ğ±)|>Ï„]â‰¤Râ‹…â„™ğ±âˆ¼Sref[|pâ¢(ğ±)|>Ï„]+Î”,â‹…ğ‘…subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†clnğ‘ğ±ğœâ‹…ğ‘…subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†refğ‘ğ±ğœÎ”R\cdot\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{cln}}}[|p(\mathbf{% x})|>\tau]\leq R\cdot\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref% }}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|>\tau]+\Delta\,,italic_R â‹… blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ ] â‰¤ italic_R â‹… blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ ] + roman_Î” ,

since Sclnsubscriptğ‘†clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Srefsubscriptğ‘†refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are both i.i.d. samples from the distribution ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğŸ™â¡{|pâ¢(ğ±)|>Ï„}1ğ‘ğ±ğœ\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{|p(\mathbf{x})|>\tau\}blackboard_1 { | italic_p ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ } is equal to the sum of two degree-â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ polynomial threshold functions, ğŸ™â¡{pâ¢(ğ±)>Ï„}+ğŸ™â¡{pâ¢(ğ±)<âˆ’Ï„}1ğ‘ğ±ğœ1ğ‘ğ±ğœ\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{p(\mathbf{x})>\tau\}+\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{p% (\mathbf{x})<-\tau\}blackboard_1 { italic_p ( bold_x ) > italic_Ï„ } + blackboard_1 { italic_p ( bold_x ) < - italic_Ï„ }. Therefore:

|{ğ±âˆˆS:|pâˆ—(ğ±)|>Ï„âˆ—}|â‰¥Râ‹…|{ğ±âˆˆScln:|pâˆ—(ğ±)|>Ï„âˆ—|,|\{\mathbf{x}\in S:|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau^{*}\}|\geq R\cdot|\{\mathbf{x}\in S% _{\mathrm{cln}}:|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|>\tau^{*}|\,,| { bold_x âˆˆ italic_S : | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } | â‰¥ italic_R â‹… | { bold_x âˆˆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | > italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ,

for any update we make. Summing over all the updates, we obtain that the total number of points removed from Sclnsubscriptğ‘†clnS_{\mathrm{cln}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by the updates of line 1 is at most

(1/R)â‹…|Sinpâˆ–Sfilt|â‹…1ğ‘…subscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘†filt(1/R)\cdot|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|( 1 / italic_R ) â‹… | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | (3.4)

By combining Eq. (3.3) and (3.4), we obtain the desired result, where the probability of failure is at most Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ due to a union bound. âˆ

So far, we have proven the first part of TheoremÂ 3.2. We will now prove the second part, by showing the following claim.

Claim.

Any polynomial pğ‘pitalic_p of degree at most â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ and ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[|pâ¢(ğ±)|]â‰¤Ïµ/(4â¢R)subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿğ‘ğ±italic-Ïµ4ğ‘…\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]\leq% \epsilon/(4R)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] â‰¤ italic_Ïµ / ( 4 italic_R ), lies within ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´ over Srefsubscriptğ‘†refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof.

Let ğ’Ÿ=ğ’Ÿâˆ—ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D = caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Fix any polynomial pğ‘pitalic_p with ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[|pâ¢(ğ±)|]â‰¤Ïµ/(4â¢R)subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿğ‘ğ±italic-Ïµ4ğ‘…\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]\leq% \epsilon/(4R)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] â‰¤ italic_Ïµ / ( 4 italic_R ). Due to the hypercontractivity of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D (DefinitionÂ 3.1), we have ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[(pâ¢(ğ±))2]â‰¤(2â¢A)2â¢â„“=Î²/2subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ‘ğ±2superscript2ğ´2â„“ğ›½2\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]% \leq(2A)^{2\ell}=\beta/2blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ ( 2 italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Î² / 2, since ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[|pâ¢(ğ±)|]â‰¤1subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿğ‘ğ±1\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]\leq 1blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] â‰¤ 1. By LemmaÂ A.1, since mrefsubscriptğ‘šrefm_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is large enough, w.p. at least 1âˆ’Î´21ğ›¿21-\frac{\delta}{2}1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG over Srefsubscriptğ‘†refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sref[(pâ¢(ğ±))2]â‰¤Î²subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†refsuperscriptğ‘ğ±2ğ›½\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{% 2}]\leq\betablackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ italic_Î².

It remains to show that with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´/21ğ›¿21-\delta/21 - italic_Î´ / 2, we have ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sref[|pâ¢(ğ±)|]â‰¤Î³=Ïµ/(2â¢R)subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†refğ‘ğ±ğ›¾italic-Ïµ2ğ‘…\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]% \leq\gamma=\epsilon/(2R)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] â‰¤ italic_Î³ = italic_Ïµ / ( 2 italic_R ). The following bound can be obtained for any tâ‰¥1ğ‘¡1t\geq 1italic_t â‰¥ 1 by applying the Marcinkiewiczâ€“Zygmund inequality (see [43]), due to the fact that Srefsubscriptğ‘†refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT consists of mrefsubscriptğ‘šrefm_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT i.i.d. examples.

â„™Srefâˆ¼ğ’Ÿmref[|ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sref[|p(ğ±)|]âˆ’ğ”¼ğ±â€²âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[|p(ğ±â€²)|]|>Ïµ4â¢R]â‰¤2(32â¢R2â¢tÏµ2â¢mref)tğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[||p(ğ±)|âˆ’ğ”¼ğ±â€²âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[|p(ğ±â€²)|]|2â¢t]\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{S_{\mathrm{ref}}\sim\mathcal{D}^{m_{\mathrm{ref}}}% }\Bigr{[}\Bigr{|}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{ref}}}[% |p(\mathbf{x})|]-\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\sim\mathcal{D% }}[|p(\mathbf{x}^{\prime})|]\Bigr{|}>\frac{\epsilon}{4R}\Bigr{]}\leq 2\Bigr{(}% \frac{32R^{2}t}{\epsilon^{2}m_{\mathrm{ref}}}\Bigr{)}^{t}\operatorname*{% \mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}\Bigr{[}\Bigr{|}|p(\mathbf{x})|-% \operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(\mathbf{x}^% {\prime})|]\Bigr{|}^{2t}\Bigr{]}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | ] | > divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 4 italic_R end_ARG ] â‰¤ 2 ( divide start_ARG 32 italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | | italic_p ( bold_x ) | - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | ] | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]

To conclude the proof of the claim, we use the simple inequality (a+b)2â¢tâ‰¤4tâ¢maxâ¡{a2â¢t,b2â¢t}superscriptğ‘ğ‘2ğ‘¡superscript4ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘2ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘2ğ‘¡(a+b)^{2t}\leq 4^{t}\max\{a^{2t},b^{2t}\}( italic_a + italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 4 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_max { italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } for all a,b,tâ‰¥0ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡0a,b,t\geq 0italic_a , italic_b , italic_t â‰¥ 0 as well as hypercontractivity to bound the expectation on the right-hand side by (8At)2â¢â„“â¢tğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[|p(ğ±)|]2â¢t(8At)^{2\ell t}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(% \mathbf{x})|]^{2t}( 8 italic_A italic_t ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_â„“ italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Due to the choice of mrefsubscriptğ‘šrefm_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, if we choose t=logâ¡(1/Î´)ğ‘¡1ğ›¿t=\log(1/\delta)italic_t = roman_log ( 1 / italic_Î´ ), we obtain a bound of Î´/2ğ›¿2\delta/2italic_Î´ / 2, as desired. âˆ

This concludes the proof of TheoremÂ 3.2. âˆ

4 Applications

4.1 Learning with Bounded Contamination

We give results for BC-learning of any concept class that can be approximated by low-degree polynomials in â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT distance.

Definition 4.1 (Polynomial Approximators).

For Ïµâˆˆ(0,1)italic-Ïµ01\epsilon\in(0,1)italic_Ïµ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ), we say that a class ğ’âŠ†{ğ’³â†’{Â±1}}ğ’â†’ğ’³plus-or-minus1\mathcal{C}\subseteq\{\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}\}caligraphic_C âŠ† { caligraphic_X â†’ { Â± 1 } } has Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximate degree â„“=â„“â¢(Ïµ)â„“â„“italic-Ïµ\ell=\ell(\epsilon)roman_â„“ = roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) with respect to some distribution ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X if for any fâˆˆğ’ğ‘“ğ’f\in\mathcal{C}italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C there is a polynomial pğ‘pitalic_p of degree at most â„“â¢(Ïµ)â„“italic-Ïµ\ell(\epsilon)roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) such that ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâˆ—[(fâ¢(ğ±)âˆ’pâ¢(ğ±))2]â‰¤Ïµsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±superscriptğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ‘“ğ±ğ‘ğ±2italic-Ïµ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[(f(\mathbf{x})-p(% \mathbf{x}))^{2}]\leq\epsilonblackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_f ( bold_x ) - italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ italic_Ïµ.

Our main result additionally requires that the target marginal distribution is hypercontractive. This assumption is inherited by TheoremÂ 3.2.

Theorem 4.2 (Polynomial Approximation implies BC-Learning).

Let Ïµ,Î´âˆˆ(0,1)italic-Ïµğ›¿01\epsilon,\delta\in(0,1)italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) and Aâ‰¥1ğ´1A\geq 1italic_A â‰¥ 1. Let ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be some Ağ´Aitalic_A-hypercontractive distribution over a dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional space and let ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be a concept class whose Ïµ4Csuperscriptitalic-Ïµ4ğ¶\frac{\epsilon^{4}}{{C}}divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG-approximate degree w.r.t. ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ for some large enough universal constant Câ‰¥1ğ¶1C\geq 1italic_C â‰¥ 1. Then, there is an algorithm that (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-learns ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C under bounded contamination with respect to ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in time polyâ¡(Aâ„“,(logâ¡1Î´)â„“,(d+1)â„“,1Ïµ)polysuperscriptğ´â„“superscript1ğ›¿â„“superscriptğ‘‘1â„“1italic-Ïµ\operatorname{poly}(A^{\ell},(\log\frac{1}{\delta})^{\ell},(d+1)^{\ell},\frac{% 1}{\epsilon})roman_poly ( italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG ), and has (clean) sample complexity at most 1Ïµ6â¢Oâ¢(Aâ¢dâ¢logâ¡(1/Î´))4â¢â„“+11superscriptitalic-Ïµ6ğ‘‚superscriptğ´ğ‘‘1ğ›¿4â„“1\frac{1}{\epsilon^{6}}O(Ad\log(1/\delta))^{4\ell+1}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_O ( italic_A italic_d roman_log ( 1 / italic_Î´ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

In TableÂ 2, we summarize some of the new results we obtain as corollaries of TheoremÂ 4.2, combined with appropriate known bounds on the approximate degree (see SectionÂ C.1). We also present the previous state-of-the-art results for comparison. For monotone functions and convex sets, no non-trivial results were known before this work. For halfspace intersections, we obtain exponential improvements over prior work, and for polynomial threshold functions, we obtain the first near-optimal error bounds. For small-depth circuits, we obtain an improved dependence on the depth.

Our results nearly match the best known upper bounds for agnostic learning, albeit with a worse dependence on the excess error parameter Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ. In particular, to achieve excess error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ, we require Oâ¢(Ïµ4)ğ‘‚superscriptitalic-Ïµ4O(\epsilon^{4})italic_O ( italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )-approximating polynomials, while for agnostic learning an Oâ¢(Ïµ2)ğ‘‚superscriptitalic-Ïµ2O(\epsilon^{2})italic_O ( italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )-approximation suffices. Therefore, our results imply, for example, a runtime of dO~(log(k)/Ïµ8d^{\tilde{O}(\log(k)/\epsilon^{8}}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( roman_log ( italic_k ) / italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for BC-learning of kğ‘˜kitalic_k-halfspace intersections with respect to ğ’©dsubscriptğ’©ğ‘‘\mathcal{N}_{d}caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but agnostic learning can be done in dO~(log(k)/Ïµ4d^{\tilde{O}(\log(k)/\epsilon^{4}}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( roman_log ( italic_k ) / italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [74].

The proof of TheoremÂ 4.2 is based on a delicate analysis of the error on the filtered dataset obtained by applying TheoremÂ 3.2. The filtering algorithm is used to preserve the following important property of any polynomial pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that approximates a boolean function:

ğ”¼[(pâˆ—â¢(ğ±))2]â‰¤1+Oâ¢(Ïµ)ğ”¼superscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ±21ğ‘‚italic-Ïµ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[(p^{*}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]\leq 1+O(\epsilon)blackboard_E [ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ 1 + italic_O ( italic_Ïµ ) (4.1)

We show that obtaining a filtered set that preserves this property is sufficient for learning with bounded contamination. To prove this, we crucially use the fact that the noise is bounded and that the right hand side of Eq. (4.1) is approximately equal to 1111 (rather than some larger constant). On the other hand, by applying part 2 of TheoremÂ 3.2 on the polynomial qâ¢(ğ±)=(pâˆ—â¢(ğ±))2âˆ’1ğ‘ğ±superscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ±21q(\mathbf{x})=(p^{*}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}-1italic_q ( bold_x ) = ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1, we are able to ensure the desired property for pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on the filtered set. We give the full proof of our main result on learning with bounded contamination (TheoremÂ 4.2) below.

Proof of TheoremÂ 4.2.

The algorithm receives a dataset SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT generated by (ğ’Ÿâˆ—,fâˆ—)superscriptğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ‘“(\mathcal{D}^{*},f^{*})( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with bounded contamination of rate Î·âˆˆ(0,1)ğœ‚01\eta\in(0,1)italic_Î· âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ), where fâˆ—âˆˆğ’superscriptğ‘“ğ’f^{*}\in\mathcal{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_C and Î·,fâˆ—ğœ‚superscriptğ‘“\eta,f^{*}italic_Î· , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are unknown, draws a set Srefsubscriptğ‘†refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of mref=(Câ€²â¢Aâ¢d)4â¢â„“Ïµ6â¢(logâ¡1Î´)8â¢â„“+1subscriptğ‘šrefsuperscriptsuperscriptğ¶â€²ğ´ğ‘‘4â„“superscriptitalic-Ïµ6superscript1ğ›¿8â„“1m_{\mathrm{ref}}=\frac{(C^{\prime}Ad)^{4\ell}}{\epsilon^{6}}(\log\frac{1}{% \delta})^{8\ell+1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 8 roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT i.i.d. unlabeled examples from ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where Câ€²â‰¥1superscriptğ¶â€²1C^{\prime}\geq 1italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ 1 is a sufficiently large universal constant and does the following.

  1. 1.

    First, the algorithm runs the filtering procedure of TheoremÂ 3.2 (that is, AlgorithmÂ 1) on input (Sinp,Sref,m=|Sinp|,2â¢â„“,R=2,24â¢Ïµ2/C)formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘†refğ‘šsubscriptğ‘†inp2â„“ğ‘…224superscriptitalic-Ïµ2ğ¶(S_{\mathrm{inp}},S_{\mathrm{ref}},m=|S_{\mathrm{inp}}|,2\ell,R=2,24\epsilon^{% 2}/{\sqrt{C}})( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m = | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | , 2 roman_â„“ , italic_R = 2 , 24 italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / square-root start_ARG italic_C end_ARG ) to form the filtered dataset SÂ¯filtsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where the labels are consistent with SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Then, the algorithm finds a polynomial p^^ğ‘\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG of degree at most â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ that minimizes the following convex objective.

    p^=argâ¡minp^ğ‘subscriptğ‘\displaystyle\widehat{p}=\arg\min_{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ğ”¼(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯filt[|yâˆ’pâ¢(ğ±)|]subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘¦ğ‘ğ±\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}}[|y-p(\mathbf{x})|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_y - italic_p ( bold_x ) | ]

  3. 3.

    The algorithm outputs hâ¢(ğ±)=signâ¡(p^â¢(ğ±)+Ï„^)â„ğ±sign^ğ‘ğ±^ğœh(\mathbf{x})=\operatorname{sign}(\widehat{p}(\mathbf{x})+\widehat{\tau})italic_h ( bold_x ) = roman_sign ( over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( bold_x ) + over^ start_ARG italic_Ï„ end_ARG ), where Ï„^âˆˆâ„^ğœâ„\widehat{\tau}\in{\mathbb{R}}over^ start_ARG italic_Ï„ end_ARG âˆˆ blackboard_R minimizes the one-dimensional objective â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯filt[yâ‰ signâ¡(p^â¢(ğ±)+Ï„)]subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘¦sign^ğ‘ğ±ğœ\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq% \operatorname{sign}(\widehat{p}(\mathbf{x})+\tau)]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  roman_sign ( over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( bold_x ) + italic_Ï„ ) ] over Ï„âˆˆâ„ğœâ„\tau\in{\mathbb{R}}italic_Ï„ âˆˆ blackboard_R.

We will now bound the error of hâ„hitalic_h on the clean dataset SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT according to which SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT was formed (see DefinitionÂ 1.1). This suffices because, due to standard VC theory, and since hâ„hitalic_h is a polynomial threshold function of degree at most â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“, as long as m=|SÂ¯cln|â‰¥Câ€²â¢(d+1)â„“+logâ¡1Î´Ïµ2ğ‘šsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnsuperscriptğ¶â€²superscriptğ‘‘1â„“1ğ›¿superscriptitalic-Ïµ2m=|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}|\geq C^{\prime}\frac{(d+1)^{\ell}+\log\frac{1}{% \delta}}{\epsilon^{2}}italic_m = | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¥ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG for some sufficiently large universal constant Câ€²â‰¥1superscriptğ¶â€²1C^{\prime}\geq 1italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ 1, we have that â„™ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[fâˆ—â¢(ğ±)â‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ‘“ğ±â„ğ±\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[f^{*}(\mathbf{x})\neq h% (\mathbf{x})]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ] is approximately equal to its empirical counterpart â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯inp[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpğ‘¦â„ğ±\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ].

Consider pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be a polynomial of degree at most â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ such that ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[(fâˆ—â¢(ğ±)âˆ’pâˆ—â¢(ğ±))2]â‰¤Ïµâ€²subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ±superscriptğ‘ğ±2superscriptitalic-Ïµâ€²\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[(f^{*}(\mathbf{x})-p^{*% }(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]\leq\epsilon^{\prime}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where Ïµâ€²=Ïµ4/Csuperscriptitalic-Ïµâ€²superscriptitalic-Ïµ4ğ¶\epsilon^{\prime}=\epsilon^{4}/{C}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_C. Since pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT approximates a Boolean-valued function fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the values of pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT should, in expectation, be close to either 1111 or âˆ’11-1- 1. In particular, we obtain the following bound using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality:

ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâˆ—[|(pâˆ—â¢(ğ±))2âˆ’1|]subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±superscriptğ’Ÿsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ±21\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[|(p^{*% }(\mathbf{x}))^{2}-1|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 | ] =ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[|(pâˆ—â¢(ğ±))2âˆ’(fâˆ—â¢(ğ±))2|]absentsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ±2superscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ±2\displaystyle=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|(p^{*}(% \mathbf{x}))^{2}-(f^{*}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}|]= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ]
=ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâˆ—[|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)âˆ’fâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|â‹…|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)+fâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|]absentsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±superscriptğ’Ÿâ‹…superscriptğ‘ğ±superscriptğ‘“ğ±superscriptğ‘ğ±superscriptğ‘“ğ±\displaystyle=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[|p^{*% }(\mathbf{x})-f^{*}(\mathbf{x})|\cdot|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})+f^{*}(\mathbf{x})|]= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | â‹… | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) + italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ]
â‰¤ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâˆ—[(pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)âˆ’fâˆ—â¢(ğ±))2]â‹…ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâˆ—[(pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)+fâˆ—â¢(ğ±))2]absentâ‹…subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±superscriptğ’Ÿsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ±superscriptğ‘“ğ±2subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±superscriptğ’Ÿsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ±superscriptğ‘“ğ±2\displaystyle\leq\sqrt{\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{% *}}[(p^{*}(\mathbf{x})-f^{*}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]}\cdot\sqrt{\operatorname*{% \mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[(p^{*}(\mathbf{x})+f^{*}(\mathbf{x% }))^{2}]}â‰¤ square-root start_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] end_ARG â‹… square-root start_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) + italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] end_ARG
â‰¤Ïµâ€²+2â¢Ïµâ€²â‰¤3â¢Ïµ2/Cabsentsuperscriptitalic-Ïµâ€²2superscriptitalic-Ïµâ€²3superscriptitalic-Ïµ2ğ¶\displaystyle\leq\epsilon^{\prime}+\sqrt{2\epsilon^{\prime}}\leq 3\epsilon^{2}% /\sqrt{C}â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + square-root start_ARG 2 italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG â‰¤ 3 italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / square-root start_ARG italic_C end_ARG (4.2)

ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Scln[|fâˆ—â¢(ğ±)âˆ’pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|]subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†clnsuperscriptğ‘“ğ±superscriptğ‘ğ±\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{cln}}}[|f^{% *}(\mathbf{x})-p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] â‰¤ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâˆ—[|fâˆ—â¢(ğ±)âˆ’pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|]+Ïµ/6absentsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±superscriptğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ‘“ğ±superscriptğ‘ğ±italic-Ïµ6\displaystyle\leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[|f% ^{*}(\mathbf{x})-p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|]+\epsilon/6â‰¤ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] + italic_Ïµ / 6
â‰¤ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâˆ—[(fâˆ—â¢(ğ±)âˆ’pâˆ—â¢(ğ±))2]+Ïµ/6absentsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±superscriptğ’Ÿsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ±superscriptğ‘ğ±2italic-Ïµ6\displaystyle\leq\sqrt{\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{% *}}[(f^{*}(\mathbf{x})-p^{*}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]}+\epsilon/6â‰¤ square-root start_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] end_ARG + italic_Ïµ / 6
â‰¤Ïµ2/C+Ïµ/6â‰¤Ïµ/3absentsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ2ğ¶italic-Ïµ6italic-Ïµ3\displaystyle\leq\epsilon^{2}/\sqrt{C}+\epsilon/6\leq\epsilon/3â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / square-root start_ARG italic_C end_ARG + italic_Ïµ / 6 â‰¤ italic_Ïµ / 3 (4.5)

For the last term in Eq. (4.4), we first use the basic fact that the variance of any random variable is non-negative and hence ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sfiltâˆ–Scln[|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|]â‰¤(ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sfiltâˆ–Scln[(pâˆ—â¢(ğ±))2])1/2subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘†clnsuperscriptğ‘ğ±superscriptsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘†clnsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ±212\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{% \mathrm{cln}}}[|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|]\leq(\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}% \sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}}[(p^{*}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}])^{1% /2}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] â‰¤ ( blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, we observe that ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sfiltâˆ–Scln[(pâˆ—â¢(ğ±))2]=ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sfiltâˆ–Scln[qâ¢(ğ±)]+1subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘†clnsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ±2subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘†clnğ‘ğ±1\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{% \mathrm{cln}}}[(p^{*}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}% \sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}}[q(\mathbf{x})]+1blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_q ( bold_x ) ] + 1. Overall, we have:

12â¢mâ¢âˆ‘ğ±âˆˆSfiltâˆ–Scln|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|12ğ‘šsubscriptğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘†clnsuperscriptğ‘ğ±\displaystyle\frac{1}{2m}\sum_{\mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{% \mathrm{cln}}}|p^{*}(\mathbf{x})|divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆˆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | â‰¤|Sfiltâˆ–Scln|2â¢m(1+ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sfiltâˆ–Scln[q(ğ±)])1/2\displaystyle\leq\frac{|S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|}{2m}\Bigr% {(}{1+\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_% {\mathrm{cln}}}[q(\mathbf{x})]}\Bigr{)}^{1/2}â‰¤ divide start_ARG | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_m end_ARG ( 1 + blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_q ( bold_x ) ] ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (4.6)

We will now bound the quantity Pâ€²=ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sfiltâˆ–Scln[qâ¢(ğ±)]=1|Sfiltâˆ–Scln|â¢âˆ‘ğ±âˆˆSfiltâˆ–Sclnqâ¢(ğ±)superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘†clnğ‘ğ±1subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘†clnsubscriptğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘†clnğ‘ğ±P^{\prime}=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}% \setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}}[q(\mathbf{x})]=\frac{1}{|S_{\mathrm{filt}}% \setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|}\sum_{\mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{% \mathrm{cln}}}q(\mathbf{x})italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_q ( bold_x ) ] = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆˆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( bold_x ).

The first inequality in the expression above follows from the guarantee of Eq. (4.3), which is provided by the filtering algorithm. 12â¢mâ¢âˆ‘ğ±âˆˆSfiltâˆ–Scln|pâˆ—â¢(ğ±)|â‰¤|Sfiltâˆ–Scln|2â¢m+ÏµCâ€²â€²/2,12ğ‘šsubscriptğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘†clnsuperscriptğ‘ğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘†cln2ğ‘šitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ¶â€²â€²2\frac{1}{2m}\sum_{\mathbf{x}\in S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}}|p% ^{*}(\mathbf{x})|\leq\frac{|S_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|}{2m}+% \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{C^{\prime\prime}/2}}\,,divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆˆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | â‰¤ divide start_ARG | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_m end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / 2 end_ARG end_ARG ,

=1mâ¢âˆ‘(ğ±,y)âˆˆSÂ¯clnâˆ©SÂ¯filtğŸ™â¡{yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)}+1mâ¢âˆ‘(ğ±,y)âˆˆSÂ¯clnâˆ–SÂ¯filtğŸ™â¡{yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)}absent1ğ‘šsubscriptğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt1ğ‘¦â„ğ±1ğ‘šsubscriptğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt1ğ‘¦â„ğ±\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cap\bar% {S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}+\frac{1}% {m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt% }}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆˆ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) } + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆˆ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) }

In order to complete the proof, we use the guarantee of AlgorithmÂ 1 that with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´/41ğ›¿41-\delta/41 - italic_Î´ / 4, we have

|(SÂ¯clnâˆ©SÂ¯inp)âˆ–SÂ¯filt|subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt\displaystyle|(\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cap\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}})\setminus\bar{% S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|| ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤12â¢|SÂ¯inpâˆ–SÂ¯filt|+Ïµâ¢m12absent12subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtitalic-Ïµğ‘š12\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{2}|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}|+\frac{\epsilon m}{12}â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 12 end_ARG

Note that the union of the sets (SÂ¯inpâˆ–SÂ¯cln)âˆ–SÂ¯filtsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt(\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}})\setminus\bar{S}_{% \mathrm{filt}}( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and SÂ¯filtâˆ–SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is disjoint and equals to the set of adversarial examples SÂ¯adv=SÂ¯inpâˆ–SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†advsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{adv}}=\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_adv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
