Therefore, we overall obtain the desired bound of

â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯cln[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]â‰¤2â¢Î·+5â¢Ïµ6.subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnğ‘¦â„ğ±2ğœ‚5italic-Ïµ6\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]\leq 2\eta+\frac{5\epsilon}{6}\,.blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ] â‰¤ 2 italic_Î· + divide start_ARG 5 italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG .

This concludes the proof of TheoremÂ 4.2. âˆ

4.2 Learning with Heavy Contamination

For heavy contamination, our results are based on the stronger notion of sandwiching approximators from pseudorandomness [3].

Definition 4.3 (Sandwiching Approximators).

For Ïµâˆˆ(0,1)italic-Ïµ01\epsilon\in(0,1)italic_Ïµ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ), we say that a class ğ’âŠ†{ğ’³â†’{Â±1}}ğ’â†’ğ’³plus-or-minus1\mathcal{C}\subseteq\{\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}\}caligraphic_C âŠ† { caligraphic_X â†’ { Â± 1 } } has Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-sandwiching degree â„“=â„“â¢(Ïµ)â„“â„“italic-Ïµ\ell=\ell(\epsilon)roman_â„“ = roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) with respect to some distribution ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X if for any fâˆˆğ’ğ‘“ğ’f\in\mathcal{C}italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C there are two polynomials pup,pdownsubscriptğ‘upsubscriptğ‘downp_{\mathrm{up}},p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of degree at most â„“â¢(Ïµ)â„“italic-Ïµ\ell(\epsilon)roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) such that:

  1. 1.

    pdownâ¢(ğ±)â‰¤fâ¢(ğ±)â‰¤pupâ¢(ğ±)subscriptğ‘downğ±ğ‘“ğ±subscriptğ‘upğ±p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})\leq f(\mathbf{x})\leq p_{\mathrm{up}}(\mathbf{x})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) â‰¤ italic_f ( bold_x ) â‰¤ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) for all ğ±âˆˆğ’³ğ±ğ’³\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{X}bold_x âˆˆ caligraphic_X and

  2. 2.

    ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâˆ—[pupâ¢(ğ±)âˆ’pdownâ¢(ğ±)]â‰¤Ïµsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±superscriptğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘upğ±subscriptğ‘downğ±italic-Ïµ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[p_{\mathrm{up}}(% \mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})]\leq\epsilonblackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] â‰¤ italic_Ïµ

Once more, our main result requires hypercontractivity of the marginal distribution.

Theorem 4.4 (Sandwiching implies HC-Learning).

Let Ïµ,Î´âˆˆ(0,1)italic-Ïµğ›¿01\epsilon,\delta\in(0,1)italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) and A,Qâ‰¥1ğ´ğ‘„1A,Q\geq 1italic_A , italic_Q â‰¥ 1. Let ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be some Ağ´Aitalic_A-hypercontractive distribution over a dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional space and let ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be a concept class whose Ïµ2Câ¢Qsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ2ğ¶ğ‘„\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{CQ}divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_C italic_Q end_ARG-sandwiching degree w.r.t. ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ for some large enough constant Câ‰¥1ğ¶1C\geq 1italic_C â‰¥ 1. Then, there is an algorithm that (Ïµ,Î´,Q)italic-Ïµğ›¿ğ‘„(\epsilon,\delta,Q)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ , italic_Q )-HC learns ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C with respect to ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in time polyâ¡(Aâ„“,(logâ¡(1/Î´))â„“,(d+1)â„“,Q/Ïµ)polysuperscriptğ´â„“superscript1ğ›¿â„“superscriptğ‘‘1â„“ğ‘„italic-Ïµ\operatorname{poly}(A^{\ell},(\log(1/\delta))^{\ell},(d+1)^{\ell},Q/\epsilon)roman_poly ( italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( roman_log ( 1 / italic_Î´ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q / italic_Ïµ ), and has (clean) sample complexity at most Q2Ïµ5â‹…Oâ¢(Aâ¢d)2â¢â„“â‹…logâ¡1Î´â‹…â‹…superscriptğ‘„2superscriptitalic-Ïµ5ğ‘‚superscriptğ´ğ‘‘2â„“1ğ›¿\frac{Q^{2}}{\epsilon^{5}}\cdot O(Ad)^{2\ell}\cdot\log\frac{1}{\delta}divide start_ARG italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG â‹… italic_O ( italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG.

In TableÂ 3, we provide a number of end-to-end results for learning with heavy contamination, which are obtained by combining TheoremÂ 4.4 with appropriate known bounds on the sandwiching degree (see SectionÂ C.2). The first row of TableÂ 3 gives the bound dO~â¢(Q2â¢k6/Ïµ4)superscriptğ‘‘~ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘„2superscriptğ‘˜6superscriptitalic-Ïµ4d^{\tilde{O}(Q^{2}k^{6}/\epsilon^{4})}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for learning intersections of kğ‘˜kitalic_k halfspaces with Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q-heavy contamination by choosing s=t=kğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘˜s=t=kitalic_s = italic_t = italic_k, as well as the bound dO~â¢(Q2â¢k4â¢4k/Ïµ4)superscriptğ‘‘~ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘„2superscriptğ‘˜4superscript4ğ‘˜superscriptitalic-Ïµ4d^{\tilde{O}(Q^{2}k^{4}4^{k}/\epsilon^{4})}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for arbitrary functions of kğ‘˜kitalic_k halfspaces, with the choice s=2kğ‘ superscript2ğ‘˜s=2^{k}italic_s = 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, t=kğ‘¡ğ‘˜t=kitalic_t = italic_k.

The proof of TheoremÂ 4.4 uses once more AlgorithmÂ 1 to filter the input set, but this time we set the hyperparameter Rğ‘…Ritalic_R to a value that scales with the heavy contamination ratio Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q. This ensures that we keep most of the clean points, because the filtering process is highly selective. Due to the choice of Rğ‘…Ritalic_R, the required sandwiching degree scales with Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q as well. As a consequence, for many classes, our bounds are exponential in Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q. After filtering, the approximation property of the sandwiching polynomials is preserved under the empirical distribution over the filtered set, and this is sufficient for efficient learnability of the optimum hypothesis on the filtered set, due to TheoremÂ A.3 by [68]. We give the full proof of our main result on learning with heavy contamination (TheoremÂ 4.4) below.

Proof of TheoremÂ 4.4.

The algorithm receives a Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q-heavily contaminated dataset SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, draws a set Srefsubscriptğ‘†refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of mref=Q2â¢(Câ€²â¢Aâ¢d)2â¢â„“Ïµ5â¢(logâ¡1Î´)4â¢â„“+1subscriptğ‘šrefsuperscriptğ‘„2superscriptsuperscriptğ¶â€²ğ´ğ‘‘2â„“superscriptitalic-Ïµ5superscript1ğ›¿4â„“1m_{\mathrm{ref}}=\frac{Q^{2}(C^{\prime}Ad)^{2\ell}}{\epsilon^{5}}(\log\frac{1}% {\delta})^{4\ell+1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT i.i.d. unlabeled examples from ğ’Ÿ=ğ’Ÿâˆ—ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D = caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where Câ€²â‰¥1superscriptğ¶â€²1C^{\prime}\geq 1italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ 1 is a sufficiently large universal constant and does the following.

  1. 1.

    First, the algorithm runs the filtering procedure of TheoremÂ 3.2 (that is, AlgorithmÂ 1) on input (Sinp,Sref,m=Q2â¢(Câ€²â¢Aâ¢d)2â¢â„“â¢logâ¡1Î´Ïµ5,â„“,R=2â¢QÏµ,Ïµ/3)formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘†refğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘„2superscriptsuperscriptğ¶â€²ğ´ğ‘‘2â„“1ğ›¿superscriptitalic-Ïµ5â„“ğ‘…2ğ‘„italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµ3(S_{\mathrm{inp}},S_{\mathrm{ref}},m=\frac{Q^{2}(C^{\prime}Ad)^{2\ell}\log% \frac{1}{\delta}}{\epsilon^{5}},\ell,R=\frac{2Q}{\epsilon},\epsilon/3)( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m = divide start_ARG italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , roman_â„“ , italic_R = divide start_ARG 2 italic_Q end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG , italic_Ïµ / 3 ) to form the filtered dataset SÂ¯filtsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Then, the algorithm finds a polynomial p^^ğ‘\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG of degree at most â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ that minimizes the following convex objective.

    p^=argâ¡minp^ğ‘subscriptğ‘\displaystyle\widehat{p}=\arg\min_{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ğ”¼(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯filt[|yâˆ’pâ¢(ğ±)|]subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘¦ğ‘ğ±\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}}[|y-p(\mathbf{x})|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_y - italic_p ( bold_x ) | ]
    s.t. pâ¢Â has degree at mostÂ â¢â„“ğ‘Â has degree at mostÂ â„“\displaystyle p\text{ has degree at most }\ellitalic_p has degree at most roman_â„“
  3. 3.

    The algorithm outputs hâ¢(ğ±)=signâ¡(p^â¢(ğ±)+Ï„^)â„ğ±sign^ğ‘ğ±^ğœh(\mathbf{x})=\operatorname{sign}(\widehat{p}(\mathbf{x})+\widehat{\tau})italic_h ( bold_x ) = roman_sign ( over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( bold_x ) + over^ start_ARG italic_Ï„ end_ARG ), where Ï„^âˆˆâ„^ğœâ„\widehat{\tau}\in{\mathbb{R}}over^ start_ARG italic_Ï„ end_ARG âˆˆ blackboard_R minimizes the one-dimensional objective â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯filt[yâ‰ signâ¡(p^â¢(ğ±)+Ï„)]subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘¦sign^ğ‘ğ±ğœ\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq% \operatorname{sign}(\widehat{p}(\mathbf{x})+\tau)]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  roman_sign ( over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( bold_x ) + italic_Ï„ ) ] over Ï„âˆˆâ„ğœâ„\tau\in{\mathbb{R}}italic_Ï„ âˆˆ blackboard_R.

We will now bound the error of hâ„hitalic_h on the clean distribution ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG. To this end, we first note that the empirical error of hâ„hitalic_h on the clean samples SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is, with high probability, close to the error on ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG, since |SÂ¯cln|subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}|| overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | is large enough and hâ„hitalic_h is a polynomial threshold function of degree at most â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“. It therefore, suffices to bound the error of hâ„hitalic_h on SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We have the following.

â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯cln[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnğ‘¦â„ğ±\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% cln}}}[y\neq h(\mathbf{x})]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ] =1mâ¢âˆ‘(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯clnâˆ©SÂ¯filtğŸ™â¡{yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)}+1mâ¢âˆ‘(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯clnâˆ–SÂ¯filtğŸ™â¡{yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)}absent1ğ‘šsubscriptsimilar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt1ğ‘¦â„ğ±1ğ‘šsubscriptsimilar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt1ğ‘¦â„ğ±\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cap% \bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}+% \frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\setminus\bar{S}_{% \mathrm{filt}}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) } + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) }
â‰¤1mâ¢âˆ‘(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯filtğŸ™â¡{yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)}+1mâ‹…|SÂ¯clnâˆ–SÂ¯filt|absent1ğ‘šsubscriptsimilar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt1ğ‘¦â„ğ±â‹…1ğ‘šsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}% \operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}+\frac{1}{m}\cdot|\bar{S}_{% \mathrm{cln}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) } + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG â‹… | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | (4.8)

The second term in the bound above can be bounded by Ïµ/3italic-Ïµ3\epsilon/3italic_Ïµ / 3, due to part 1 of TheoremÂ 3.2. It remains to bound the first term.

Consider fâˆ—âˆˆğ’superscriptğ‘“ğ’f^{*}\in\mathcal{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_C to be the concept in class ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C with minimum error on SÂ¯filtsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., we have that fâˆ—=argâ¡minfâˆˆğ’â¢â„™(ğ±,y)âˆˆSÂ¯filt[yâ‰ fâ¢(ğ±)]superscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘“ğ’subscriptâ„™ğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ±f^{*}=\arg\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in% \bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆˆ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_f ( bold_x ) ]. Note that there is some fâ€²âˆˆğ’superscriptğ‘“â€²ğ’f^{\prime}\in\mathcal{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_C that makes at most Mâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalâ‹…ğ‘€subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalM\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}italic_M â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT errors on the whole input dataset SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, due to the definition of ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalsubscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see DefinitionÂ 1.4). Moreover, let pup,pdownsubscriptğ‘upsubscriptğ‘downp_{\mathrm{up}},p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the Ïµ272â¢Qsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ272ğ‘„\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{72Q}divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 72 italic_Q end_ARG-sandwiching polynomials for fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and p=pupâˆ’pdownğ‘subscriptğ‘upsubscriptğ‘downp=p_{\mathrm{up}}-p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is a non-negative polynomial with ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[|pâ¢(ğ±)|]â‰¤Ïµ272â¢Qsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿğ‘ğ±superscriptitalic-Ïµ272ğ‘„\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[|p(\mathbf{x})|]\leq% \frac{\epsilon^{2}}{72Q}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 72 italic_Q end_ARG. Due to part 2 of TheoremÂ 3.2, the expectation of pğ‘pitalic_p under Sfiltsubscriptğ‘†filtS_{\mathrm{filt}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is at most Ïµâ¢m3â¢|SÂ¯filt|italic-Ïµğ‘š3subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt\frac{\epsilon m}{3|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 3 | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG, i.e., ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sfilt[pupâ¢(ğ±)âˆ’pdownâ¢(ğ±)]â‰¤Ïµâ¢m3â¢|SÂ¯filt|subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘upğ±subscriptğ‘downğ±italic-Ïµğ‘š3subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}}[p_{\mathrm{up}}(% \mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})]\leq\frac{\epsilon m}{3|\bar{S}_{% \mathrm{filt}}|}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 3 | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG. Since pupâ‰¥fâˆ—â‰¥pdownsubscriptğ‘upsuperscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘downp_{\mathrm{up}}\geq f^{*}\geq p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we also have that

ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sfilt[|fâˆ—â¢(ğ±)âˆ’pdownâ¢(ğ±)|]â‰¤Ïµâ¢m3â¢|SÂ¯filt|subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsuperscriptğ‘“ğ±subscriptğ‘downğ±italic-Ïµğ‘š3subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}}}[|f^{*}(\mathbf{x% })-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})|]\leq\frac{\epsilon m}{3|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}|}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) | ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 3 | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG

We now observe that hâ„hitalic_h is the output of the â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT polynomial regression algorithm on SÂ¯filtsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and, therefore, according to TheoremÂ A.3 by [68], we overall have the following bound

â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯filt[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]â‰¤M|SÂ¯filt|â‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total+Ïµâ¢m3â¢|SÂ¯filt|,subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘¦â„ğ±â‹…ğ‘€subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtsubscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalitalic-Ïµğ‘š3subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq h% (\mathbf{x})]\leq\frac{M}{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm% {total}}+\frac{\epsilon m}{3|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}\,,blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_M end_ARG start_ARG | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 3 | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG ,

which implies the desired bound:

1mâ¢âˆ‘(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯filtğŸ™â¡{yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)}â‰¤Mmâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total+Ïµâ¢m2â‰¤Qâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total+Ïµ/31ğ‘šsubscriptsimilar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt1ğ‘¦â„ğ±â‹…ğ‘€ğ‘šsubscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalitalic-Ïµğ‘š2â‹…ğ‘„subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalitalic-Ïµ3\frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}\operatorname{% \mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}\leq\frac{M}{m}\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{% total}}+\frac{\epsilon m}{2}\leq Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}+\epsilon/3divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) } â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_M end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG â‰¤ italic_Q â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Ïµ / 3 (4.9)

The result follows by combining Eq. (4.8) and (4.9). âˆ

Remark 4.5.

Our result on HC-learning highlights the following analogy:

  • â€¢

    Learning with heavy contamination can be thought of as a version of testable agnostic learning (DefinitionÂ 4.7), where the algorithm is asked to find a subset of the input that is structured enough, instead of merely verifying whether the whole input is structured.

  • â€¢

    Similarly, in the context of learning with distribution shift, PQ learning [49] requires finding a subset of an unlabeled test dataset where the learner is confident in its own predictions, while TDS learning [78] aims to verify whether the whole unlabeled test dataset is drawn from some distribution that is similar to the one the learner has trained on.

  • â€¢

    In [54], it is shown that by using a spectral iterative filtering algorithm, TDS learning results can be extended to PQ learning. Here, we complete the analogy by showing that our iterative filtering algorithm can extend known results from testable learning (i.e., that sandwiching is sufficient, see [48]) to HC-learning.

Remark 4.6.

One could define a hybrid model where a bounded fraction of clean points are replaced adversarially and a proportionally large number of adversarial points are then added. Our results should apply to this setting as well, but we focus on BC and HC learning separately for simplicity of presentation.

4.3 Tolerant Testable Learning

We give new results for testable learning [83] and tolerant testable learning [54].

Definition 4.7 (Tolerant Testable Learning [54]).

An algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is a tolerant tester-learner for ğ’âŠ†{ğ’³â†’{Â±1}}ğ’â†’ğ’³plus-or-minus1\mathcal{C}\subseteq\{\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}\}caligraphic_C âŠ† { caligraphic_X â†’ { Â± 1 } } with respect to some target distribution ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X if on input (Ïµ,Î´,Ï„,SÂ¯inp)italic-Ïµğ›¿ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp(\epsilon,\delta,\tau,\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}})( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ , italic_Ï„ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where Ïµ,Ï„,Î´âˆˆ(0,1)italic-Ïµğœğ›¿01\epsilon,\tau,\delta\in(0,1)italic_Ïµ , italic_Ï„ , italic_Î´ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) and SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a set of i.i.d. examples from some arbitrary distribution ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG, the algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A outputs either outputs RejectReject\mathrm{Reject}roman_Reject or outputs (Accept,h)Acceptâ„(\mathrm{Accept},h)( roman_Accept , italic_h ), where h:ğ’³â†’{Â±1}:â„â†’ğ’³plus-or-minus1h:\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}italic_h : caligraphic_X â†’ { Â± 1 } such that with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´ over SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the randomness of ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A, the following conditions hold.

  1. 1.

    (Soundness) Upon acceptance, the error of hâ„hitalic_h is bounded as follows:

    â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]â‰¤minfâˆˆğ’â¢â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯[yâ‰ fâ¢(ğ±)]+Ï„+Ïµsubscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦Â¯ğ’Ÿğ‘¦â„ğ±subscriptğ‘“ğ’subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦Â¯ğ’Ÿğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ±ğœitalic-Ïµ\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]\leq\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},% y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]+\tau+\epsilonblackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ] â‰¤ roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_f ( bold_x ) ] + italic_Ï„ + italic_Ïµ
  2. 2.

    (Completeness) If dTVâ¢(ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâˆ—)â‰¤Ï„subscriptdTVğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿğœ\mathrm{d}_{\mathrm{TV}}(\mathcal{D},{\mathcal{D}^{*}})\leq\tauroman_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_TV end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_Ï„, where ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D is the marginal of ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG on ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X, then ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A accepts.

The sample complexity of ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is the minimum number of examples required to achieve the above guarantee.

Previous work by [54] showed that the existence of â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sandwiching polynomials with bounded coefficients, i.e., polynomials pup,pdownsubscriptğ‘upsubscriptğ‘downp_{\mathrm{up}},p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâˆ—[(pupâ¢(ğ±)âˆ’pdownâ¢(ğ±))2]â‰¤Ïµsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±superscriptğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘upğ±subscriptğ‘downğ±2italic-Ïµ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[(p_{\mathrm{up}}(% \mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]\leq\epsilonblackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ italic_Ïµ implies tolerant testable learning. Here, we relax this condition to â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sandwiching polynomials (DefinitionÂ 4.3), without requiring any bound on the coefficients. Note that even for non-tolerant testable learning, where â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sandwiching is known to suffice [48], all prior work required bounds on the coefficients.

Theorem 4.8 (Sandwiching implies Tolerant Testable Learning).

Let Ïµ,Î´,Ï„âˆˆ(0,1)italic-Ïµğ›¿ğœ01\epsilon,\delta,\tau\in(0,1)italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ , italic_Ï„ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) and Qâ‰¥1ğ‘„1Q\geq 1italic_Q â‰¥ 1. Let ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be some Ağ´Aitalic_A-hypercontractive distribution over a dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional space and let ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be a concept class whose ÏµCâ¢(1+Ï„/Ïµ)italic-Ïµğ¶1ğœitalic-Ïµ\frac{\epsilon}{C(1+\tau/\epsilon)}divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG italic_C ( 1 + italic_Ï„ / italic_Ïµ ) end_ARG-sandwiching degree w.r.t. ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ for some large enough constant Câ‰¥1ğ¶1C\geq 1italic_C â‰¥ 1. Then, there is an (Ïµ,Î´,Ï„)italic-Ïµğ›¿ğœ(\epsilon,\delta,\tau)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ , italic_Ï„ )-tester-learner for ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C w.r.t. ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with runtime polyâ¡(Aâ„“,(logâ¡(1/Î´))â„“,(d+1)â„“,1/Ïµ)polysuperscriptğ´â„“superscript1ğ›¿â„“superscriptğ‘‘1â„“1italic-Ïµ\operatorname{poly}(A^{\ell},(\log(1/\delta))^{\ell},(d+1)^{\ell},1/\epsilon)roman_poly ( italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( roman_log ( 1 / italic_Î´ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 1 / italic_Ïµ ), and sample complexity at most 1Ïµ5â‹…Oâ¢(Aâ¢d)2â¢â„“â‹…logâ¡1Î´â‹…â‹…1superscriptitalic-Ïµ5ğ‘‚superscriptğ´ğ‘‘2â„“1ğ›¿\frac{1}{\epsilon^{5}}\cdot O(Ad)^{2\ell}\cdot\log\frac{1}{\delta}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG â‹… italic_O ( italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG.

The following corollary follows from TheoremÂ 4.8, combined with the fact that log-concave distributions are hypercontractive (see [10]), as well as the results of [73, 67] on the sandwiching degree of functions of halfspaces (see SectionÂ C.2). This is the first result for testably learning even a single halfspace with respect to log-concave distributions up to optimal error.

Corollary 4.9.

Let ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be the class of arbitrary functions of kğ‘˜kitalic_k halfspaces over â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\mathbb{R}}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and let ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be any log-concave distribution. There is an (Ïµ,Î´,Ï„)italic-Ïµğ›¿ğœ(\epsilon,\delta,\tau)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ , italic_Ï„ )-tester-learner for ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C with respect to ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that runs in time (dâ¢logâ¡(1/Î´))O~â¢(â„“)superscriptğ‘‘1ğ›¿~ğ‘‚â„“(d\log(1/\delta))^{\tilde{O}(\ell)}( italic_d roman_log ( 1 / italic_Î´ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( roman_â„“ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where â„“=expâ¡((logâ¡(logâ¡(k)/Ïµ))Oâ¢(k)/Ïµ8)â„“superscriptğ‘˜italic-Ïµğ‘‚ğ‘˜superscriptitalic-Ïµ8\ell=\exp((\log(\log(k)/\epsilon))^{O(k)}/\epsilon^{8})roman_â„“ = roman_exp ( ( roman_log ( roman_log ( italic_k ) / italic_Ïµ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

We will now prove TheoremÂ 4.8, using once more the iterative polynomial filtering algorithm of TheoremÂ 3.2.

Proof of TheoremÂ 4.8.

The algorithm receives a dataset SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, draws a reference set Srefsubscriptğ‘†refS_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of mref=(Câ€²â¢Aâ¢d)2â¢â„“Ïµ5â¢(logâ¡1Î´)4â¢â„“+1subscriptğ‘šrefsuperscriptsuperscriptğ¶â€²ğ´ğ‘‘2â„“superscriptitalic-Ïµ5superscript1ğ›¿4â„“1m_{\mathrm{ref}}=\frac{(C^{\prime}Ad)^{2\ell}}{\epsilon^{5}}(\log\frac{1}{% \delta})^{4\ell+1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT i.i.d. unlabeled examples from ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, where Câ€²â‰¥1superscriptğ¶â€²1C^{\prime}\geq 1italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ 1 is a sufficiently large universal constant and does the following.

  1. 1.

    First, the algorithm runs the filtering procedure of TheoremÂ 3.2 (that is, AlgorithmÂ 1) on input (Sinp,Sref,m=|Sinp|,â„“,R=4â¢Ï„Ïµ+2,Ïµ/8)formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘†refğ‘šsubscriptğ‘†inpâ„“ğ‘…4ğœitalic-Ïµ2italic-Ïµ8(S_{\mathrm{inp}},S_{\mathrm{ref}},m=|S_{\mathrm{inp}}|,\ell,R=\frac{4\tau}{% \epsilon}+{2},\epsilon/8)( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m = | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | , roman_â„“ , italic_R = divide start_ARG 4 italic_Ï„ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG + 2 , italic_Ïµ / 8 ) to form the filtered dataset SÂ¯filtsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Then, the algorithm checks if mâˆ’|SÂ¯filt|â‰¤(Ï„+Ïµ/2)â¢mğ‘šsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğœitalic-Ïµ2ğ‘šm-|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|\leq(\tau+\epsilon/2)mitalic_m - | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤ ( italic_Ï„ + italic_Ïµ / 2 ) italic_m and rejects if the inequality does not hold.

  3. 3.

    Otherwise, the algorithm finds a polynomial p^^ğ‘\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG of degree at most â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ that minimizes the following convex objective.

    p^=argâ¡minp^ğ‘subscriptğ‘\displaystyle\widehat{p}=\arg\min_{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ğ”¼(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯filt[|yâˆ’pâ¢(ğ±)|]subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘¦ğ‘ğ±\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}}[|y-p(\mathbf{x})|]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_y - italic_p ( bold_x ) | ]
    s.t. pâ¢Â has degree at mostÂ â¢â„“ğ‘Â has degree at mostÂ â„“\displaystyle p\text{ has degree at most }\ellitalic_p has degree at most roman_â„“
  4. 4.

    The algorithm outputs hâ¢(ğ±)=signâ¡(p^â¢(ğ±)+Ï„^)â„ğ±sign^ğ‘ğ±^ğœh(\mathbf{x})=\operatorname{sign}(\widehat{p}(\mathbf{x})+\widehat{\tau})italic_h ( bold_x ) = roman_sign ( over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( bold_x ) + over^ start_ARG italic_Ï„ end_ARG ), where Ï„^âˆˆâ„^ğœâ„\widehat{\tau}\in{\mathbb{R}}over^ start_ARG italic_Ï„ end_ARG âˆˆ blackboard_R minimizes the one-dimensional objective â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯filt[yâ‰ signâ¡(p^â¢(ğ±)+Ï„)]subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘¦sign^ğ‘ğ±ğœ\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq% \operatorname{sign}(\widehat{p}(\mathbf{x})+\tau)]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  roman_sign ( over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( bold_x ) + italic_Ï„ ) ] over Ï„âˆˆâ„ğœâ„\tau\in{\mathbb{R}}italic_Ï„ âˆˆ blackboard_R.

Soundness.

Suppose, first, that the algorithm accepts. Observe that |SÂ¯inpâˆ–SÂ¯filt|=|SÂ¯inp|âˆ’|SÂ¯filt|subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|=|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp% }}|-|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|| overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | - | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |, since SÂ¯filtâŠ†SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}\subseteq\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since the algorithm has accepted, we know the following.

|SÂ¯inp|âˆ’|SÂ¯filt|=mâˆ’|SÂ¯filt|â‰¤mâ¢(Ï„+Ïµ/2)subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘šsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘šğœitalic-Ïµ2|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}|-|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|=m-|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|% \leq m(\tau+\epsilon/2)| overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | - | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = italic_m - | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤ italic_m ( italic_Ï„ + italic_Ïµ / 2 )

Recall that SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a set of mğ‘šmitalic_m i.i.d. examples from the input distribution ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG. Since mğ‘šmitalic_m is large enough, due to standard VC dimension arguments (and the fact that hâ„hitalic_h is a polynomial threshold function of degree at most â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“), we have that with high probability:

â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]â‰¤â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯inp[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]+Ïµ/4subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦Â¯ğ’Ÿğ‘¦â„ğ±subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpğ‘¦â„ğ±italic-Ïµ4\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]\leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm% {inp}}}[y\neq h(\mathbf{x})]+\epsilon/4blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ] â‰¤ blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ] + italic_Ïµ / 4 (4.10)

Therefore, it suffices to show a bound on the empirical error of hâ„hitalic_h on SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We have the following:

â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯inp[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpğ‘¦â„ğ±\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% inp}}}[y\neq h(\mathbf{x})]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ] =1mâ¢âˆ‘(ğ±,y)âˆˆSÂ¯inpâˆ–SÂ¯filtğŸ™â¡{yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)}+1mâ¢âˆ‘(ğ±,y)âˆˆSÂ¯filtğŸ™â¡{yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)}absent1ğ‘šsubscriptğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt1ğ‘¦â„ğ±1ğ‘šsubscriptğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt1ğ‘¦â„ğ±\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}% \setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x% })\}+\frac{1}{m}\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}\operatorname{% \mathbbm{1}}\{y\neq h(\mathbf{x})\}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆˆ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) } + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆˆ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) }
â‰¤1mâ¢|SÂ¯inpâˆ–SÂ¯filt|+|SÂ¯filt|mâ¢â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯filt[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]absent1ğ‘šsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘šsubscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘¦â„ğ±\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{m}|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}|+\frac{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}{m}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(% \mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq h(\mathbf{x})]â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + divide start_ARG | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ]
â‰¤Ï„+Ïµ2+|SÂ¯filt|mâ¢â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯filt[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]absentğœitalic-Ïµ2subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘šsubscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘¦â„ğ±\displaystyle\leq\tau+\frac{\epsilon}{2}+\frac{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}{m}% \operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq h% (\mathbf{x})]â‰¤ italic_Ï„ + divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + divide start_ARG | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ]

It suffices to show that â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯filt[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]â‰¤m|SÂ¯filt|â¢(minfâˆˆğ’â¢â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]+Ïµ/4)subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘¦â„ğ±ğ‘šsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘“ğ’subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦Â¯ğ’Ÿğ‘¦â„ğ±italic-Ïµ4\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}}[y\neq h% (\mathbf{x})]\leq\frac{m}{|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|}(\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}% \operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]+\epsilon/4)blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG ( roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ] + italic_Ïµ / 4 ). Let fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the function that minimizes the error on ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG and let pup,pdownsubscriptğ‘upsubscriptğ‘downp_{\mathrm{up}},p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be its Ïµ2128â¢Ï„+64â¢Ïµsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ2128ğœ64italic-Ïµ\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{128\tau+64\epsilon}divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 128 italic_Ï„ + 64 italic_Ïµ end_ARG-sandwiching polynomials. Then according to part 2 of TheoremÂ 3.2, and since for p=pupâˆ’pdownğ‘subscriptğ‘upsubscriptğ‘downp=p_{\mathrm{up}}-p_{\mathrm{down}}italic_p = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we have ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[pâ¢(ğ±)]â‰¤Ïµ2128â¢Ï„+64â¢Ïµsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿğ‘ğ±superscriptitalic-Ïµ2128ğœ64italic-Ïµ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[p(\mathbf{x})]\leq\frac% {\epsilon^{2}}{128\tau+64\epsilon}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p ( bold_x ) ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 128 italic_Ï„ + 64 italic_Ïµ end_ARG, we obtain:

|Sfilt|â¢ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼Sfilt[pupâ¢(ğ±)âˆ’pdownâ¢(ğ±)]=âˆ‘ğ±âˆˆSfilt(pupâ¢(ğ±)âˆ’pdownâ¢(ğ±))â‰¤Ïµâ¢m8subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘upğ±subscriptğ‘downğ±subscriptğ±subscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘upğ±subscriptğ‘downğ±italic-Ïµğ‘š8|S_{\mathrm{filt}}|\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S_{\mathrm{filt}% }}[p_{\mathrm{up}}(\mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x})]=\sum_{\mathbf{x}% \in S_{\mathrm{filt}}}(p_{\mathrm{up}}(\mathbf{x})-p_{\mathrm{down}}(\mathbf{x% }))\leq\frac{\epsilon m}{8}| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ] = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆˆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_up end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_down end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG

Overall, we have the following bound:

â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯inp[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]â‰¤ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—+Ï„+3â¢Ïµ/4,subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpğ‘¦â„ğ±ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—ğœ3italic-Ïµ4\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]\leq\mathsf{opt}+\tau+3\epsilon/4\,,blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ] â‰¤ sansserif_opt + italic_Ï„ + 3 italic_Ïµ / 4 ,

which, together with the generalization bound of Eq. (4.10) implies the soundness of the algorithm.

Completeness.

We will now show that the algorithm accepts with high probability whenever dTVâ¢(ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâˆ—)â‰¤Ï„subscriptdTVğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿğœ\mathrm{d}_{\mathrm{TV}}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{*})\leq\tauroman_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_TV end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_Ï„. It suffices to show that |SÂ¯inpâˆ–SÂ¯filt|â‰¤(Ï„+Ïµ/2)â¢msubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğœitalic-Ïµ2ğ‘š|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|\leq(\tau+\epsilon/2)m| overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤ ( italic_Ï„ + italic_Ïµ / 2 ) italic_m with high probability, since |SÂ¯inpâˆ–SÂ¯filt|=mâˆ’|SÂ¯filt|subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘šsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filt|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|=m-|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{% filt}}|| overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = italic_m - | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |, which is exactly the quantity based upon which the algorithm decides whether to reject or not.

Let Scln={ğ±(1),ğ±(2),â€¦,ğ±(m)}subscriptğ‘†clnsuperscriptğ±1superscriptğ±2â€¦superscriptğ±ğ‘šS_{\mathrm{cln}}=\{\mathbf{x}^{(1)},\mathbf{x}^{(2)},\dots,\mathbf{x}^{(m)}\}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } be a set of mğ‘šmitalic_m i.i.d. examples drawn from ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. Note that the distribution of each ğ³(i)superscriptğ³ğ‘–\mathbf{z}^{(i)}bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and they are drawn independently. According to TheoremÂ 3.2, we have the following, with high probability:

Observe, now, that |Sinpâˆ–Sfilt|=|(Sinpâˆ©Scln)âˆ–Sfilt|+|Sinpâˆ–Scln|subscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘†clnsubscriptğ‘†filtsubscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘†cln|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|=|(S_{\mathrm{inp}}\cap S_{% \mathrm{cln}})\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|+|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{% \mathrm{cln}}|| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = | ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |. Therefore, if we solve for |Sinpâˆ–Sfilt|subscriptğ‘†inpsubscriptğ‘†filt|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}|| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |, we have the following

(1âˆ’1R)â‹…|Sinpâˆ–Sfilt|â‰¤|Sinpâˆ–Scln|+Ïµâ¢m8â‰¤m(Ï„+Ïµ/4)\Bigr{(}1-\frac{1}{R}\Bigr{)}\cdot|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{filt}}% |\leq|S_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus S_{\mathrm{cln}}|+\frac{\epsilon m}{8}\leq m(% \tau+\epsilon/4)( 1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_R end_ARG ) â‹… | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤ | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG â‰¤ italic_m ( italic_Ï„ + italic_Ïµ / 4 )

Due to the choice of Rğ‘…Ritalic_R, we have the desired bound |SÂ¯inpâˆ–SÂ¯filt|â‰¤mâ¢(Ï„+Ïµ/2)subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†filtğ‘šğœitalic-Ïµ2|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\setminus\bar{S}_{\mathrm{filt}}|\leq m(\tau+\epsilon/2)| overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ– overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_filt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤ italic_m ( italic_Ï„ + italic_Ïµ / 2 ). âˆ

5 Lower Bounds for Learning with Contamination

5.1 Bounded Contamination

Although the problem of learning from contaminated datasets is, in principle, more challenging than learning with label noise, it is not clear whether the common formulations of the former are formally stronger than those of the latter. In particular, the problem of learning with label noise is usually formalized in terms of agnostic learning, where the goal is to achieve error ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—+Ïµğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—italic-Ïµ\mathsf{opt}+\epsilonsansserif_opt + italic_Ïµ on the input distribution ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG for ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—=minfâˆˆğ’â¢â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯[yâ‰ fâ¢(ğ±)]ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—subscriptğ‘“ğ’subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦Â¯ğ’Ÿğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ±\mathsf{opt}=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)% \sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]sansserif_opt = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_f ( bold_x ) ], where ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C is the learned class. In contrast, learning with contamination is usually formulated as learning with nasty noise, where the goal is to achieve error 2â¢Î·+Ïµ2ğœ‚italic-Ïµ2\eta+\epsilon2 italic_Î· + italic_Ïµ on the target distribution (ğ’Ÿâˆ—,fâˆ—)superscriptğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ‘“(\mathcal{D}^{*},f^{*})( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where fâˆ—âˆˆğ’superscriptğ‘“ğ’f^{*}\in\mathcal{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_C and Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· is the noise rate. Therefore, given an algorithm for learning with contamination, one may obtain an agnostic learner with error guarantee 3â¢ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—+Ïµ3ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—italic-Ïµ3\mathsf{opt}+\epsilon3 sansserif_opt + italic_Ïµ, but it is not clear whether the guarantee of ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—+Ïµğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—italic-Ïµ\mathsf{opt}+\epsilonsansserif_opt + italic_Ïµ can be achieved in a black-box way. This is because in one formulation the error is measured with respect to the input distribution and in the other it is measured with respect to the clean target distribution.

Furthermore, many of the lower bounds for agnostic learning seem to exclusively rule out algorithms with error guarantees of ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—+Ïµğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—italic-Ïµ\mathsf{opt}+\epsilonsansserif_opt + italic_Ïµ [37]. Therefore, these lower bounds do not transfer directly to learning with bounded contamination as defined in DefinitionÂ 1.1. One natural way to go around this, is to observe that our result in TheoremÂ 4.2 would also hold for the following stronger version of DefinitionÂ 1.1.

Definition 5.1 (Agnostic BC-Learning).

An algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is an agnostic BC-learner for ğ’âŠ†{ğ’³â†’{Â±1}}ğ’â†’ğ’³plus-or-minus1\mathcal{C}\subseteq\{\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}\}caligraphic_C âŠ† { caligraphic_X â†’ { Â± 1 } } if on input (Ïµ,Î´,SÂ¯inp)italic-Ïµğ›¿subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp(\epsilon,\delta,\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}})( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where Ïµ,Î´âˆˆ(0,1)italic-Ïµğ›¿01\epsilon,\delta\in(0,1)italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ), and SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is generated by ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG with bounded contamination Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· for some labeled distribution ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG, and Î·âˆˆ[0,1)ğœ‚01\eta\in[0,1)italic_Î· âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ), the algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A outputs some hypothesis h:ğ’³â†’{Â±1}:â„â†’ğ’³plus-or-minus1h:\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}italic_h : caligraphic_X â†’ { Â± 1 } such that with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´ over the clean examples in SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the randomness of ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A:

â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]â‰¤2â¢Î·+ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—clean+Ïµ,Â whereÂ â¢ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—clean=minfâˆˆğ’â¢â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯[yâ‰ fâ¢(ğ±)]formulae-sequencesubscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦Â¯ğ’Ÿğ‘¦â„ğ±2ğœ‚subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—cleanitalic-ÏµÂ whereÂ subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—cleansubscriptğ‘“ğ’subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦Â¯ğ’Ÿğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ±\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq h(% \mathbf{x})]\leq 2\eta+\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}+\epsilon\,,\text{ where }% \mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}% _{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ] â‰¤ 2 italic_Î· + sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Ïµ , where sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_f ( bold_x ) ]

The sample complexity of ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is the minimum number of examples required to achieve the above guarantee. Moreover, a distribution-specific BC-learner with respect to some distribution ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ{\mathcal{D}^{*}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X is a BC-learner that is guaranteed to work only when ğ’Ÿ=ğ’Ÿâˆ—ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}={\mathcal{D}^{*}}caligraphic_D = caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Note that DefinitionÂ 5.1 is a generalization of agnostic learning, since one can obtain agnostic learning by setting Î·=0ğœ‚0\eta=0italic_Î· = 0. Our TheoremÂ 4.2 holds even under this definition, and all the lower bounds for agnostic learning (TableÂ 4) are also inherited. For example, our results indicate that a runtime of dpolyâ¡(1Ïµ,logâ¡k)superscriptğ‘‘poly1italic-Ïµğ‘˜d^{\operatorname{poly}(\frac{1}{\epsilon},\log k)}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_poly ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG , roman_log italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is both sufficient and necessary for learning intersections of kğ‘˜kitalic_k halfspaces in the agnostic BC setting. However, agnostic learning is known to be characterized by the â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-approximate degree [68, 42, 37], whereas we require the stronger assumption of low â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-approximate degree. Therefore, while for most interesting classes our results are essentially tight, a complete characterization of efficient learnability in the setting of DefinitionÂ 5.1 remains open.

5.2 Heavy Contamination

We provide an information-theoretic lower bound for learning monotone functions with heavy contamination. Our lower bound highlights a separation between bounded and heavy contamination and justifies the need for a stronger notion of approximation than standard polynomial approximators. In particular, monotone functions over {Â±1}dsuperscriptplus-or-minus1ğ‘‘\{\pm 1\}^{d}{ Â± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are known to admit Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximate polynomials of degree â„“â¢(Ïµ)=d/Ïµâ„“italic-Ïµğ‘‘italic-Ïµ\ell(\epsilon)=\sqrt{d}/\epsilonroman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) = square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG / italic_Ïµ, and hence admit a BC-learner that runs in time 2Oâ¢(d)superscript2ğ‘‚ğ‘‘2^{{O}(\sqrt{d})}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for Ïµ=1/4italic-Ïµ14\epsilon=1/4italic_Ïµ = 1 / 4, but we show that every HC learner requires 2Î©â¢(d)superscript2Î©ğ‘‘2^{\Omega(d)}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î© ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT samples (and runtime).

Theorem 5.2 (Lower Bound for HC-Learning of Monotone Functions).

Let ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be the class of monotone functions over {Â±1}dsuperscriptplus-or-minus1ğ‘‘\{\pm 1\}^{d}{ Â± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Any HC-learner for ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C with respect to the uniform distribution over the hypercube Unifâ¡({Â±1}d)Unifsuperscriptplus-or-minus1ğ‘‘\operatorname{Unif}(\{\pm 1\}^{d})roman_Unif ( { Â± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) requires sample complexity 2Î©â¢(d)superscript2Î©ğ‘‘2^{\Omega(d)}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î© ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, even when Ïµ=1/4italic-Ïµ14\epsilon=1/4italic_Ïµ = 1 / 4, Q=2ğ‘„2Q=2italic_Q = 2 and Î´=1/3ğ›¿13\delta=1/3italic_Î´ = 1 / 3.

Proof of TheoremÂ 5.2.

Suppose that the ground truth is a constant function, i.e., either fâˆ—â‰¡1superscriptğ‘“1f^{*}\equiv 1italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¡ 1 or fâˆ—â‰¡âˆ’1superscriptğ‘“1f^{*}\equiv-1italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¡ - 1, and that mâ‰¤2d/10/10ğ‘šsuperscript2ğ‘‘1010m\leq 2^{d/10}/10italic_m â‰¤ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d / 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / 10. Then, the adversary receives the mğ‘šmitalic_m clean examples SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and draws mğ‘šmitalic_m additional i.i.d. examples Sâ€²superscriptğ‘†â€²S^{\prime}italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from Unifâ¡({Â±1}d)Unifsuperscriptplus-or-minus1ğ‘‘\operatorname{Unif}(\{\pm 1\}^{d})roman_Unif ( { Â± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), labeling them according to âˆ’fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“-f^{*}- italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The input dataset is SÂ¯inp=SÂ¯clnâˆªSÂ¯â€²subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘†â€²\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}=\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cup\bar{S}^{\prime}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆª overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Note, first, that no algorithm can achieve error better than 1/2121/21 / 2 with probability at least 1/2121/21 / 2, since guessing fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT randomly is an optimal strategy because the distribution of the input dataset SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is exactly the same in the two cases corresponding to fâˆ—â‰¡âˆ’1superscriptğ‘“1f^{*}\equiv-1italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¡ - 1 and fâˆ—â‰¡1superscriptğ‘“1f^{*}\equiv 1italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¡ 1. We will show that Qâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total=0â‹…ğ‘„subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total0Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=0italic_Q â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 with high probability over the choice of SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Let ğ±,ğ±â€²ğ±superscriptğ±â€²\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}bold_x , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be two independent samples from Unifâ¡({Â±1}d)Unifsuperscriptplus-or-minus1ğ‘‘\operatorname{Unif}(\{\pm 1\}^{d})roman_Unif ( { Â± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). We say that ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}bold_x and ğ±â€²superscriptğ±â€²\mathbf{x}^{\prime}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are comparable if ğ±â‰¤ğ±â€²ğ±superscriptğ±â€²\mathbf{x}\leq\mathbf{x}^{\prime}bold_x â‰¤ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or ğ±â€²â‰¤ğ±superscriptğ±â€²ğ±\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\leq\mathbf{x}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ bold_x, i.e., if ğ±â¢(i)â‰¤ğ±â€²â¢(i)ğ±ğ‘–superscriptğ±â€²ğ‘–\mathbf{x}(i)\leq\mathbf{x}^{\prime}(i)bold_x ( italic_i ) â‰¤ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) for all iğ‘–iitalic_i or ğ±â€²â¢(i)â‰¤ğ±â¢(i)superscriptğ±â€²ğ‘–ğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{x}^{\prime}(i)\leq\mathbf{x}(i)bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) â‰¤ bold_x ( italic_i ) for all iğ‘–iitalic_i. Since the coordinates are independent, we have

â„™ğ±,ğ±â€²[ğ±â¢(i)â‰¤ğ±â€²â¢(i),Â for allÂ â¢iâˆˆ[d]]=âˆiâˆˆ[d]â„™ğ±,ğ±â€²[ğ±â¢(i)â‰¤ğ±â€²â¢(i)]=(3/4)dsubscriptâ„™ğ±superscriptğ±â€²ğ±ğ‘–superscriptğ±â€²ğ‘–Â for allÂ ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘‘subscriptproductğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘‘subscriptâ„™ğ±superscriptğ±â€²ğ±ğ‘–superscriptğ±â€²ğ‘–superscript34ğ‘‘\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}}[\mathbf{x}(i)\leq% \mathbf{x}^{\prime}(i)\,,\text{ for all }i\in[d]]=\prod_{i\in[d]}\operatorname% *{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}}[\mathbf{x}(i)\leq\mathbf{x}^{% \prime}(i)]=(3/4)^{d}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_x ( italic_i ) â‰¤ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) , for all italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_d ] ] = âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_d ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_x ( italic_i ) â‰¤ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) ] = ( 3 / 4 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

Similarly, for the other direction we have that â„™ğ±,ğ±â€²[ğ±â¢(i)â‰¥ğ±â€²â¢(i),Â for allÂ â¢iâˆˆ[d]]â‰¤(3/4)dsubscriptâ„™ğ±superscriptğ±â€²ğ±ğ‘–superscriptğ±â€²ğ‘–Â for allÂ ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘‘superscript34ğ‘‘\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}}[\mathbf{x}(i)\geq% \mathbf{x}^{\prime}(i)\,,\text{ for all }i\in[d]]\leq(3/4)^{d}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_x ( italic_i ) â‰¥ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) , for all italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_d ] ] â‰¤ ( 3 / 4 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and, overall, that â„™ğ±,ğ±â€²[ğ±,ğ±â€²â¢Â are comparable]â‰¤2â‹…(3/4)dsubscriptâ„™ğ±superscriptğ±â€²ğ±superscriptğ±â€²Â are comparableâ‹…2superscript34ğ‘‘\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}}[\mathbf{x},\mathbf% {x}^{\prime}\text{ are comparable}]\leq 2\cdot(3/4)^{d}blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_x , bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are comparable ] â‰¤ 2 â‹… ( 3 / 4 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

We have a set SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of 2â¢m2ğ‘š2m2 italic_m examples. It suffices to show that no pair of examples in Sinpsubscriptğ‘†inpS_{\mathrm{inp}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is comparable, because, then, any labeling of these examples is consistent with some monotone function and, hence, ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total=0subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total0\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=0sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0. We overall have at most 4â¢m24superscriptğ‘š24m^{2}4 italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT pairs and each of them is comparable with probability at most 2â‹…(3/4)dâ‹…2superscript34ğ‘‘2\cdot(3/4)^{d}2 â‹… ( 3 / 4 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, by a union bound, the probability that there is a pair that is comparable is at most 8â¢m2â¢(3/4)dâ‰¤1/108superscriptğ‘š2superscript34ğ‘‘1108m^{2}(3/4)^{d}\leq 1/108 italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 3 / 4 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 1 / 10. âˆ

6 Discussion

In this work, we lay the groundwork for a systematic study of efficient learning algorithms in the presence of contamination. For bounded contamination, we showed that low-degree appriximators suffice, nearly matching the best upper bounds for learning under label noiseâ€”a significantly milder noise model. Our results capture the challenging setting of heavy contamination as well, for classes with low sandwiching degree. Central to our approach is the iterative polynomial filtering algorithm, which is related to outlier removal procedures with a long history in the literature of robust learning and optimization (see [72, 38, 29, 30, 54, 79] and references therein). There are several interesting directions for future work:

  1. 1.

    Universality: Our algorithms require samples from the target unlabeled distribution ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Relaxing this requirement and obtaining algorithms that work universally with respect to broad classes of distributions is an important question. This is known to be possible for several problems in learning with label noise [11, 1, 41], robust unsupervised learning [75, 76, 26], as well as testable learning [50, 18].

  2. 2.

    Characterization of Efficient Learnability under Contamination: We show that â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT polynomial approximation suffices for efficient BC-learning and â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sandwiching suffices for efficient HC-learning. Determining whether the weaker notion of â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation is sufficient for BC-learning or relaxing the sandwiching requirement for HC-learning are both interesting open directions for future work.

  3. 3.

    Improved Error Guarantees: Our algorithms obtain error guarantees that are proven to be optimal in general (see PropositionÂ B.3). However, it is an open question whether one can achieve error Î·+Ïµğœ‚italic-Ïµ\eta+\epsilonitalic_Î· + italic_Ïµ for BC-learning or error 12â¢(Qâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total+ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—clean)+Ïµ12â‹…ğ‘„subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalsubscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—cleanitalic-Ïµ\frac{1}{2}(Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}+\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}})+\epsilondivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_Q â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_Ïµ for HC-learning for special classes and distributions, perhaps by allowing the learner to output randomized hypotheses (also known as probabilistic concepts).

  4. 4.

    Heavy Contamination without Label Noise: Our definition for learning with heavy contamination allows the adversary to add arbitrary labeled examples, as long as the resulting contaminated dataset can be approximately labeled by some classifier in the learned class up to a small number of mistakes. Note that the optimal classifier can also be chosen adversarially, in the sense that we do not require that the optimal classifier for the contaminated dataset be the same as the optimal classifier on the clean distribution. This property is crucially used in our lower bound for learning monotone functions with heavy contamination (TheoremÂ 5.2): the hard instance is perfectly labeled by some monotone function, but this monotone function is far from the one that generates the clean labels.

    On the other hand, even in the realizable HC settingâ€”where the clean labels are given by some concept fâˆ—âˆˆğ’superscriptğ‘“ğ’f^{*}\in\mathcal{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_C and the adversary is required to add points of the form (ğ±,fâˆ—â¢(ğ±))ğ±superscriptğ‘“ğ±(\mathbf{x},f^{*}(\mathbf{x}))( bold_x , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x ) )â€”it is not clear when efficient learning is possible. This is because for many classes, the assumptions on the distribution of ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}bold_x are crucial, even in the absence of label noise. It is therefore an interesting open question whether improved HC-learning guarantees can be achieved in the realizable setting.

Appendix A Additional Tools

In our proofs, we make use of the following results for hypercontractive distributions.

Lemma A.1 (Loewner Concentration, Lemma 3.8 in [19], Lemma B.1 in [54]).

Let ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D be some Ağ´Aitalic_A-hypercontractive distribution in dğ‘‘ditalic_d dimensions and let Sğ‘†Sitalic_S be a set of mğ‘šmitalic_m i.i.d. examples from ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D where mâ‰¥(Câ¢Aâ¢d)2â¢â„“â¢(logâ¡1Î´)4â¢â„“+1ğ‘šsuperscriptğ¶ğ´ğ‘‘2â„“superscript1ğ›¿4â„“1m\geq(CAd)^{2\ell}(\log\frac{1}{\delta})^{4\ell+1}italic_m â‰¥ ( italic_C italic_A italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some sufficiently large universal constant Câ‰¥1ğ¶1C\geq 1italic_C â‰¥ 1, Î´âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¿01\delta\in(0,1)italic_Î´ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) and A,â„“,dâ‰¥1ğ´â„“ğ‘‘1A,\ell,d\geq 1italic_A , roman_â„“ , italic_d â‰¥ 1. Then, with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´ over Sğ‘†Sitalic_S the following condition holds.

12â¢ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[(pâ¢(ğ±))2]â‰¤ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼S[(pâ¢(ğ±))2]â‰¤2â¢ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[(pâ¢(ğ±))2],Â for anyÂ â¢pâ¢Â of degree at mostÂ â¢â„“formulae-sequence12subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ‘ğ±2subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ‘†superscriptğ‘ğ±22subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ‘ğ±2Â for anyÂ ğ‘Â of degree at mostÂ â„“\frac{1}{2}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[(p(\mathbf{x% }))^{2}]\leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]% \leq 2\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{% 2}]\,,\,\text{ for any }p\text{ of degree at most }\elldivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ 2 blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] , for any italic_p of degree at most roman_â„“
Lemma A.2.
