Proof of LemmaÂ A.2.

We first apply LemmaÂ A.1 to show that, with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´ over Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, for any pâˆˆğ’«Î²â¢(S)ğ‘subscriptğ’«ğ›½ğ‘†p\in\mathcal{P}_{\beta}(S)italic_p âˆˆ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ) we have ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[(pâ¢(ğ±))2]â‰¤2â¢ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼S[(pâ¢(ğ±))2]â‰¤2â¢Î²subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ‘ğ±22subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ‘†superscriptğ‘ğ±22ğ›½\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]% \leq 2\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]\leq 2\betablackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ 2 blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ 2 italic_Î².

Consider now the moment matrix ğŒ=ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[Ïˆâ„“â¢(ğ±)â¢Ïˆâ„“â¢(ğ±)âŠ¤]ğŒsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿsubscriptğœ“â„“ğ±subscriptğœ“â„“superscriptğ±top\mathbf{M}=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[\psi_{\ell}(% \mathbf{x})\psi_{\ell}(\mathbf{x})^{\top}]bold_M = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], where Ïˆâ„“â¢(ğ±)subscriptğœ“â„“ğ±\psi_{\ell}(\mathbf{x})italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) is the vector whose coordinates correspond to monomials of ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}bold_x of degree at most â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“. Let ğŒ=ğ”ğƒğ”âŠ¤ğŒsuperscriptğ”ğƒğ”top\mathbf{M}=\mathbf{U}\mathbf{D}\mathbf{U}^{\top}bold_M = bold_UDU start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the concise SVD of ğŒğŒ\mathbf{M}bold_M, i.e., ğƒğƒ\mathbf{D}bold_D is diagonal with dimension equal to the rank of ğŒğŒ\mathbf{M}bold_M, ğ”âŠ¤â¢ğ”=ğˆsuperscriptğ”topğ”ğˆ\mathbf{U}^{\top}\mathbf{U}=\mathbf{I}bold_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_U = bold_I and ğ”ğ”âŠ¤superscriptğ”ğ”top\mathbf{U}\mathbf{U}^{\top}bold_UU start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the orthogonal projection on the column (or row) space of ğŒğŒ\mathbf{M}bold_M. Let Ï†â¢(ğ±)=ğƒâˆ’1/2â¢ğ”âŠ¤â¢Ïˆâ„“â¢(ğ±)ğœ‘ğ±superscriptğƒ12superscriptğ”topsubscriptğœ“â„“ğ±\varphi(\mathbf{x})=\mathbf{D}^{-1/2}\mathbf{U}^{\top}\psi_{\ell}(\mathbf{x})italic_Ï† ( bold_x ) = bold_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) and observe that ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[Ï†â¢(ğ±)â¢Ï†â¢(ğ±)âŠ¤]=ğˆsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿğœ‘ğ±ğœ‘superscriptğ±topğˆ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}[\varphi(\mathbf{x})% \varphi(\mathbf{x})^{\top}]=\mathbf{I}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ï† ( bold_x ) italic_Ï† ( bold_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = bold_I and the dimension of Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï† is equal to the rank of ğŒğŒ\mathbf{M}bold_M, which is at most (d+1)â„“superscriptğ‘‘1â„“(d+1)^{\ell}( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Here, we use the fact that all the entries of ğŒğŒ\mathbf{M}bold_M are finite, due to hypercontractivity.

We may express any polynomial pğ‘pitalic_p in ğ’«Î²â¢(S)subscriptğ’«ğ›½ğ‘†\mathcal{P}_{\beta}(S)caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ) as a linear combination of the elements of Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï†, i.e., pâ¢(ğ±)=ğœ~pâŠ¤â¢Ï†â¢(ğ±)ğ‘ğ±superscriptsubscript~ğœğ‘topğœ‘ğ±p(\mathbf{x})=\tilde{\mathbf{c}}_{p}^{\top}\varphi(\mathbf{x})italic_p ( bold_x ) = over~ start_ARG bold_c end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï† ( bold_x ), where â€–ğœ~pâ€–22=ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[(pâ¢(ğ±))2]â‰¤2â¢Î²superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript~ğœğ‘22subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ‘ğ±22ğ›½\|\tilde{\mathbf{c}}_{p}\|_{2}^{2}=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim% \mathcal{D}}[(p(\mathbf{x}))^{2}]\leq 2\betaâˆ¥ over~ start_ARG bold_c end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_p ( bold_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ 2 italic_Î². Moreover, we have the following due to Markovâ€™s inequality and the fact that ğ”¼[â€–Ï†â¢(ğ±)â€–22]â‰¤(d+1)â„“ğ”¼superscriptsubscriptnormğœ‘ğ±22superscriptğ‘‘1â„“\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[\|\varphi(\mathbf{x})\|_{2}^{2}]\leq(d+1)^{\ell}blackboard_E [ âˆ¥ italic_Ï† ( bold_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

â„™ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ[âˆ¥Ï†(ğ±)âˆ¥22>B22â¢Î²]â‰¤2â¢Î²â¢(d+1)â„“B2â‰¤Ïµ\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}}\Bigr{[}\|\varphi(% \mathbf{x})\|_{2}^{2}>\frac{B^{2}}{2\beta}\Bigr{]}\leq\frac{2\beta(d+1)^{\ell}% }{B^{2}}\leq\epsilonblackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ¥ italic_Ï† ( bold_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > divide start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Î² end_ARG ] â‰¤ divide start_ARG 2 italic_Î² ( italic_d + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG â‰¤ italic_Ïµ

In the event that â€–Ï†â¢(ğ±)â€–22â‰¤B22â¢Î²superscriptsubscriptnormğœ‘ğ±22superscriptğµ22ğ›½\|\varphi(\mathbf{x})\|_{2}^{2}\leq\frac{B^{2}}{2\beta}âˆ¥ italic_Ï† ( bold_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Î² end_ARG, we have |pâ¢(ğ±)|â‰¤â€–ğœ~pâ€–2â¢â€–Ï†â¢(ğ±)â€–2â‰¤2â¢Î²â‹…B2â¢Î²=Bğ‘ğ±subscriptnormsubscript~ğœğ‘2subscriptnormğœ‘ğ±2â‹…2ğ›½ğµ2ğ›½ğµ|p(\mathbf{x})|\leq\|\tilde{\mathbf{c}}_{p}\|_{2}\|\varphi(\mathbf{x})\|_{2}% \leq\sqrt{2\beta}\cdot\frac{B}{\sqrt{2\beta}}=B| italic_p ( bold_x ) | â‰¤ âˆ¥ over~ start_ARG bold_c end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï† ( bold_x ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ square-root start_ARG 2 italic_Î² end_ARG â‹… divide start_ARG italic_B end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 italic_Î² end_ARG end_ARG = italic_B. âˆ

We will also use the following theorem which is implicit in [68] and shows that polynomial approximation is sufficient to find a simple hypothesis with near-optimum error on a given dataset.

Theorem A.3 (â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT polynomial regression [68]).

Let SÂ¯Â¯ğ‘†\bar{S}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG be a set of labeled examples and ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be a concept class such that for each fâˆˆğ’ğ‘“ğ’f\in\mathcal{C}italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C there is some polynomial pğ‘pitalic_p of degree at most â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ such that ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼S[|fâ¢(ğ±)âˆ’pâ¢(ğ±)|]â‰¤Ïµsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±ğ‘†ğ‘“ğ±ğ‘ğ±italic-Ïµ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim S}[|f(\mathbf{x})-p(\mathbf{x})|]\leq\epsilonblackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_f ( bold_x ) - italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] â‰¤ italic_Ïµ. Then, the degree-â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT polynomial regression algorithm of [68] outputs, in time polyâ¡(|SÂ¯|â¢dâ„“/Ïµ)polyÂ¯ğ‘†superscriptğ‘‘â„“italic-Ïµ\operatorname{poly}(\lvert\bar{S}\rvert d^{\ell}/\epsilon)roman_poly ( | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG | italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Ïµ ), a degree-â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ polynomial threshold function hâ„hitalic_h such that â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯[yâ‰ hâ¢(ğ±)]â‰¤minfâˆˆğ’â¢â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯[yâ‰ fâ¢(ğ±)]+Ïµsubscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘†ğ‘¦â„ğ±subscriptğ‘“ğ’subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘†ğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ±italic-Ïµ\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}}[y\neq h(\mathbf{x})]% \leq\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S% }}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]+\epsilonblackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_h ( bold_x ) ] â‰¤ roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_f ( bold_x ) ] + italic_Ïµ.

We also give the definition of â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximating polynomials, which are sufficient for agnostic learning, but it is not clear whether they suffice for BC-learning. We instead use the notion of â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximating polynomials (DefinitionÂ 4.1).

Definition A.4 (â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Polynomial Approximators).

For Ïµâˆˆ(0,1)italic-Ïµ01\epsilon\in(0,1)italic_Ïµ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ), we say that a class ğ’âŠ†{ğ’³â†’{Â±1}}ğ’â†’ğ’³plus-or-minus1\mathcal{C}\subseteq\{\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}\}caligraphic_C âŠ† { caligraphic_X â†’ { Â± 1 } } has Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximate degree â„“=â„“â¢(Ïµ)â„“â„“italic-Ïµ\ell=\ell(\epsilon)roman_â„“ = roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) with respect to some distribution ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X if for any fâˆˆğ’ğ‘“ğ’f\in\mathcal{C}italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C there is a polynomial pğ‘pitalic_p of degree at most â„“â¢(Ïµ)â„“italic-Ïµ\ell(\epsilon)roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) such that ğ”¼ğ±âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâˆ—[|fâ¢(ğ±)âˆ’pâ¢(ğ±)|]â‰¤Ïµsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğ±superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘“ğ±ğ‘ğ±italic-Ïµ\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{D}^{*}}[|f(\mathbf{x})-p(% \mathbf{x})|]\leq\epsilonblackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_f ( bold_x ) - italic_p ( bold_x ) | ] â‰¤ italic_Ïµ.

The difference between â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximators is that the former enjoy the approximation property with respect to the â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm, while the latter with respect to the â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm. Achieving â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation is, in general, a stronger assumption, because the â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm is upper bounded by the â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm, but not vice versa. Nevertheless, for most interesting classes that â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximators are known, we also have â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximators. This is because of analytic advantages of the â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm.

Appendix B Error Lower Bounds for HC-Learning

In order to prove our lower bounds, we provide a definition for the adversary in the context of heavy contamination.

Definition B.1 (Contamination Strategy).

An algorithm â„³â„³\cal Mcaligraphic_M is called a (randomized) Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q-HC strategy if, upon receiving a labeled set SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it outputs a set SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of size |SÂ¯inp|â‰¤Qâ¢|SÂ¯cln|subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpğ‘„subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}|\leq Q|\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}|| overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤ italic_Q | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | such that SÂ¯inpâŠ†SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\subseteq\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For mâˆˆâ„•ğ‘šâ„•m\in\mathbb{N}italic_m âˆˆ blackboard_N and a labeled distribution ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG, we denote with â„³â¢(ğ’ŸÂ¯m)â„³superscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿğ‘š{\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}^{m})caligraphic_M ( overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) the distribution of the output SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of â„³â„³\cal Mcaligraphic_M on a set of mğ‘šmitalic_m i.i.d. samples SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG. Note that SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT depends on the random choice of SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as well as the randomness of â„³â„³\cal Mcaligraphic_M.

We first prove the following lower bound, which holds for any non-trivial concept class.

Proposition B.2.

Let ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C be any concept class such that there is some fâˆˆğ’ğ‘“ğ’f\in\mathcal{C}italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C for which âˆ’fâˆˆğ’ğ‘“ğ’-f\in\mathcal{C}- italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C. For any Qâˆˆ{2,3,â€¦}ğ‘„23â€¦Q\in\{2,3,\dots\}italic_Q âˆˆ { 2 , 3 , â€¦ }, any unlabeled distribution ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, any Ïâˆˆ[0,1/2)ğœŒ012\rho\in[0,1/2)italic_Ï âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 / 2 ), Ïµ,Î´>0italic-Ïµğ›¿0\epsilon,\delta>0italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ > 0, and any mâ‰¥logâ¡(2/Î´)2â¢Ïµ2ğ‘š2ğ›¿2superscriptitalic-Ïµ2m\geq\frac{\log(2/\delta)}{2\epsilon^{2}}italic_m â‰¥ divide start_ARG roman_log ( 2 / italic_Î´ ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG, there is a Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q-HC strategy â„³â„³\cal Mcaligraphic_M and a distribution ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG whose marginal is ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that, if we let ğ’ŸÂ¯â€²superscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿâ€²\bar{\mathcal{D}}^{\prime}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the distribution of (ğ±,âˆ’y)ğ±ğ‘¦(\mathbf{x},-y)( bold_x , - italic_y ), where (ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯similar-toğ±ğ‘¦Â¯ğ’Ÿ(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG, then the following hold.

  1. 1.

    â„³â¢(ğ’ŸÂ¯m)=â„³â¢((ğ’ŸÂ¯â€²)m)â„³superscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿğ‘šâ„³superscriptsuperscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿâ€²ğ‘š{\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}^{m})={\cal M}((\bar{\mathcal{D}}^{\prime})^{m})caligraphic_M ( overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_M ( ( overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

  2. 2.

    minfâˆˆğ’â¢â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯[yâ‰ fâ¢(ğ±)]=minfâˆˆğ’â¢â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯â€²[yâ‰ fâ¢(ğ±)]=Ïsubscriptğ‘“ğ’subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦Â¯ğ’Ÿğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ±subscriptğ‘“ğ’subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦superscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿâ€²ğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ±ğœŒ\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{% \mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{% \mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}^{\prime}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})% ]=\rhoroman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_f ( bold_x ) ] = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_f ( bold_x ) ] = italic_Ï.

  3. 3.

    With probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´ over SÂ¯inpâˆ¼â„³â¢(ğ’ŸÂ¯m)similar-tosubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpâ„³superscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿğ‘š\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}\sim{\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}^{m})overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ caligraphic_M ( overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), we have Qâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalâ‰¤1âˆ’Ï+Ïµâ‹…ğ‘„subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total1ğœŒitalic-ÏµQ\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}\leq 1-\rho+\epsilonitalic_Q â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 1 - italic_Ï + italic_Ïµ, where ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total=minfâˆˆğ’â¢â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼SÂ¯inp[yâ‰ fâ¢(ğ±)]subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalsubscriptğ‘“ğ’subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inpğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ±\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}% _{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_f ( bold_x ) ].

Hence, no HC-learner for ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C with respect to ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can achieve error less than 12â¢(Qâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total+ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—cleanâˆ’Ïµ)12â‹…ğ‘„subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalsubscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—cleanitalic-Ïµ\frac{1}{2}(Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}+\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}-\epsilon)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_Q â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ïµ ) with probability more than 12âˆ’Î´12ğ›¿\frac{1}{2}-\deltadivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - italic_Î´, even when ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—clean=Ïsubscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—cleanğœŒ\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}=\rhosansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ï.

Proof of PropositionÂ B.2.

Let ğ’Ÿ=ğ’Ÿâˆ—ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}^{*}caligraphic_D = caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Consider the following two labeled distributions. y1={fâ¢(ğ±),Â with probabilityÂ â¢1âˆ’Ïâˆ’fâ¢(ğ±),Â with probabilityÂ â¢Ïsubscriptğ‘¦1casesğ‘“ğ±Â with probabilityÂ 1ğœŒotherwiseğ‘“ğ±Â with probabilityÂ ğœŒotherwisey_{1}=\begin{cases}f(\mathbf{x}),\text{ with probability }1-\rho\\ -f(\mathbf{x}),\text{ with probability }\rho\end{cases}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_f ( bold_x ) , with probability 1 - italic_Ï end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - italic_f ( bold_x ) , with probability italic_Ï end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW

Consider also a distribution ğ’ŸÂ¯2subscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ2\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{2}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT whose marginal is also ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D but the labels are generated as follows:

The adversary receives a set SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of mğ‘šmitalic_m i.i.d. samples from ğ’ŸÂ¯âˆˆ{ğ’ŸÂ¯1,ğ’ŸÂ¯2}Â¯ğ’ŸsubscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ1subscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ2\bar{\mathcal{D}}\in\{\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1},\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{2}\}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG âˆˆ { overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and does the following.

  1. 1.

    First, the adversary computes the value m1=âˆ‘(ğ±,y)âˆˆSÂ¯inpğŸ™â¡{y=fâ¢(ğ±)}subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp1ğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ±m_{1}=\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}% \{y=f(\mathbf{x})\}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆˆ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y = italic_f ( bold_x ) }, as well as the value m2=âˆ‘(ğ±,y)âˆˆSÂ¯inpğŸ™â¡{y=âˆ’fâ¢(ğ±)}subscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp1ğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ±m_{2}=\sum_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}}\operatorname{\mathbbm{1}}% \{y=-f(\mathbf{x})\}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆˆ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 { italic_y = - italic_f ( bold_x ) }.

  2. 2.

    If m1â‰¥m2subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2m_{1}\geq m_{2}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then the adversary adds Mâˆ’mğ‘€ğ‘šM-mitalic_M - italic_m examples drawn by ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and labeled by âˆ’fâ¢(ğ±)ğ‘“ğ±-f(\mathbf{x})- italic_f ( bold_x ).

    If m1<m2subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2m_{1}<m_{2}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then the adversary adds m2âˆ’m1subscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘š1m_{2}-m_{1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT examples drawn by ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and labeled by fâ¢(ğ±)ğ‘“ğ±f(\mathbf{x})italic_f ( bold_x ), as well as Mâˆ’2â¢m2ğ‘€2subscriptğ‘š2M-2m_{2}italic_M - 2 italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT examples drawn by ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and labeled by âˆ’fâ¢(ğ±)ğ‘“ğ±-f(\mathbf{x})- italic_f ( bold_x ).

Part 1.

Let Î¾=miğœ‰subscriptğ‘šğ‘–\xi=m_{i}italic_Î¾ = italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where iâˆˆ{1,2}ğ‘–12i\in\{1,2\}italic_i âˆˆ { 1 , 2 } such that ğ’ŸÂ¯=ğ’ŸÂ¯iÂ¯ğ’ŸsubscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿğ‘–\bar{\mathcal{D}}=\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{i}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Part 2.

Follows immediately from the fact that f,âˆ’fâˆˆğ’ğ‘“ğ‘“ğ’f,-f\in\mathcal{C}italic_f , - italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C and the definition of ğ’ŸÂ¯=ğ’ŸÂ¯1Â¯ğ’ŸsubscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ1\bar{\mathcal{D}}=\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ğ’ŸÂ¯â€²=ğ’ŸÂ¯2superscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿâ€²subscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ2\bar{\mathcal{D}}^{\prime}=\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{2}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Part 3.

Regarding the error benchmark, we have Qâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total=maxâ¡{Î¾,mâˆ’Î¾}mâ‰¤1âˆ’Ï+Ïµâ‹…ğ‘„subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalğœ‰ğ‘šğœ‰ğ‘š1ğœŒitalic-ÏµQ\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=\frac{\max\{\xi,m-\xi\}}{m}\leq 1-\rho+\epsilonitalic_Q â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG roman_max { italic_Î¾ , italic_m - italic_Î¾ } end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG â‰¤ 1 - italic_Ï + italic_Ïµ, whenever |Î¾âˆ’(1âˆ’Ï)â¢m|â‰¤Ïµâ¢mğœ‰1ğœŒğ‘šitalic-Ïµğ‘š|\xi-(1-\rho)m|\leq\epsilon m| italic_Î¾ - ( 1 - italic_Ï ) italic_m | â‰¤ italic_Ïµ italic_m, which happens with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´, according to the following inequality.

â„™[|Î¾âˆ’(1âˆ’Ï)â¢m|>Ïµâ¢m]â‰¤2â¢expâ¡(âˆ’2â¢Ïµ2â¢m)â‰¤Î´â„™ğœ‰1ğœŒğ‘šitalic-Ïµğ‘š22superscriptitalic-Ïµ2ğ‘šğ›¿\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}[|\xi-(1-\rho)m|>\epsilon m]\leq 2\exp(% -2\epsilon^{2}m)\leq\deltablackboard_P [ | italic_Î¾ - ( 1 - italic_Ï ) italic_m | > italic_Ïµ italic_m ] â‰¤ 2 roman_exp ( - 2 italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m ) â‰¤ italic_Î´

The bound follows from an application of Hoeffdingâ€™s inequality, since Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ is binomial of mean (1âˆ’Ï)â¢m1ğœŒğ‘š(1-\rho)m( 1 - italic_Ï ) italic_m. It follows that with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´, the algorithm outputs a hypothesis with error at least 12â¢(Qâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total+ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—cleanâˆ’Ïµ)12â‹…ğ‘„subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalsubscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—cleanitalic-Ïµ\frac{1}{2}(Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}+\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}-\epsilon)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_Q â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ïµ ).

Implication to HC Learning.

We have â„³â¢(ğ’ŸÂ¯1m)=â„³â¢(ğ’ŸÂ¯2m)â„³superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ1ğ‘šâ„³superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ2ğ‘š{\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1}^{m})={\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{2}^{m})caligraphic_M ( overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_M ( overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Let ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A be any, potentially randomized algorithm, and let h:=ğ’œâ¢(â„³â¢(ğ’ŸÂ¯1m))=ğ’œâ¢(â„³â¢(ğ’ŸÂ¯2m))assignâ„ğ’œâ„³superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ1ğ‘šğ’œâ„³superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ2ğ‘šh:=\mathcal{A}({\cal M}(\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1}^{m}))=\mathcal{A}({\cal M}(\bar{% \mathcal{D}}_{2}^{m}))italic_h := caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_M ( overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) = caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_M ( overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) be the random variable corresponding to its output, where h:ğ’³â†’{Â±1}:â„â†’ğ’³plus-or-minus1h:\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}italic_h : caligraphic_X â†’ { Â± 1 }. Consider the event that hâ„hitalic_h is such that: â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯1[hâ¢(ğ±)â‰ y]<1/2subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ1â„ğ±ğ‘¦12\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1}}[h(\mathbf% {x})\neq y]<1/2blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_h ( bold_x ) â‰  italic_y ] < 1 / 2. Then, we have:

â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯2[hâ¢(ğ±)â‰ âˆ’y]subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ2â„ğ±ğ‘¦\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{% 2}}[h(\mathbf{x})\neq-y]blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_h ( bold_x ) â‰  - italic_y ] =â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯1[hâ¢(ğ±)â‰ âˆ’y]=1âˆ’â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯1[hâ¢(ğ±)â‰ y]>1/2absentsubscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ1â„ğ±ğ‘¦1subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ1â„ğ±ğ‘¦12\displaystyle=\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}_% {1}}[h(\mathbf{x})\neq-y]=1-\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar% {\mathcal{D}}_{1}}[h(\mathbf{x})\neq y]>1/2= blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_h ( bold_x ) â‰  - italic_y ] = 1 - blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_h ( bold_x ) â‰  italic_y ] > 1 / 2

Note that the same is true even if hâ„hitalic_h is a randomized classifier. Overall, the error of ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A on either ğ’ŸÂ¯1subscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ1\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{1}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or ğ’ŸÂ¯2subscriptÂ¯ğ’Ÿ2\bar{\mathcal{D}}_{2}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is 1/2121/21 / 2 with probability at least 1/2121/21 / 2. Finally, due to part 3, with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´, we have 1/2â‰¥12â¢(Qâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total+ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—cleanâˆ’Ïµ)1212â‹…ğ‘„subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—totalsubscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—cleanitalic-Ïµ1/2\geq\frac{1}{2}(Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}+\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{% clean}}-\epsilon)1 / 2 â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_Q â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ïµ ), which implies the desired result. âˆ

For finite feature spaces and the particular choice of the class of all functions, we obtain a sharper information-theoretic lower bound on the error. Note that this lower bound captures the problem of HC-learning halfspaces over {Â±1}plus-or-minus1\{\pm 1\}{ Â± 1 } in one dimension.

Proposition B.3.

Suppose that |ğ’³|<âˆğ’³|\mathcal{X}|<\infty| caligraphic_X | < âˆ and ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C is any concept class from ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X to {Â±1}plus-or-minus1\{\pm 1\}{ Â± 1 }. Then, on any value of Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q in {2,3,â€¦}23â€¦\{2,3,\dots\}{ 2 , 3 , â€¦ }, any (distribution-specific) HC-learner will output a hypothesis with error 1111 with probability at least 2âˆ’|ğ’³|superscript2ğ’³2^{-|\mathcal{X}|}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - | caligraphic_X | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on some instance where Qâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total=1â‹…ğ‘„subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total1Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=1italic_Q â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. Moreover, if ğ’={Â±1}ğ’³ğ’superscriptplus-or-minus1ğ’³\mathcal{C}=\{\pm 1\}^{\mathcal{X}}caligraphic_C = { Â± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then the instance satisfies ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—clean=0subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—clean0\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}=0sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.

Proof of PropositionÂ B.3.

The adversary receives the clean dataset SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and creates a duplicate SÂ¯clnâ€²superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnâ€²\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}^{\prime}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where all the labels are flipped but the feature vectors are unchanged. Then, the adversary draws (Qâˆ’2)â‹…mâ‹…ğ‘„2ğ‘š(Q-2)\cdot m( italic_Q - 2 ) â‹… italic_m i.i.d. examples Sâ€²superscriptğ‘†â€²S^{\prime}italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from the marginal distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D on ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X of the clean distribution ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG and labels them according to f1subscriptğ‘“1f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The input dataset is SÂ¯clnâˆªSÂ¯clnâ€²âˆªSÂ¯â€²subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnsuperscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnâ€²superscriptÂ¯ğ‘†â€²\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cup\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}^{\prime}\cup\bar{S}^{\prime}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆª overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆª overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Note that the input dataset is completely independent from the clean labels, since SÂ¯clnâˆªSÂ¯clnâ€²subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnsuperscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnâ€²\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cup\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}^{\prime}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆª overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be constructed equivalently by choosing an arbitrary function g:ğ’³â†’{Â±1}:ğ‘”â†’ğ’³plus-or-minus1g:\mathcal{X}\to\{\pm 1\}italic_g : caligraphic_X â†’ { Â± 1 } to label the points in SÂ¯clnsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†cln\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and then label the points in SÂ¯clnâ€²superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnâ€²\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}^{\prime}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT according to âˆ’gğ‘”-g- italic_g.

Therefore, we may assume that the ground truth labels are generated by the function fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where âˆ’fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“-f^{*}- italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the most likely output of the HC-learner on a dataset of the form SÂ¯clnâˆªSÂ¯clnâ€²âˆªSÂ¯â€²subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnsuperscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†clnâ€²superscriptÂ¯ğ‘†â€²\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}\cup\bar{S}_{\mathrm{cln}}^{\prime}\cup\bar{S}^{\prime}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆª overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cln end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆª overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Since there are at most 2|ğ’³|superscript2ğ’³2^{|\mathcal{X}|}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_X | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT possible functions, ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A must output âˆ’fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“-f^{*}- italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with probability at least 2âˆ’|ğ’³|superscript2ğ’³2^{-|\mathcal{X}|}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - | caligraphic_X | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. When ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A outputs âˆ’fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“-f^{*}- italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the error is 1111.

Finally, note that f1subscriptğ‘“1f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT achieves error on SÂ¯inpsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†inp\bar{S}_{\mathrm{inp}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_inp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equal to 1/Q1ğ‘„1/Q1 / italic_Q, so ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total=1/Qsubscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total1ğ‘„\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=1/Qsansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 / italic_Q and Qâ‹…ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total=1â‹…ğ‘„subscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—total1Q\cdot\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{total}}=1italic_Q â‹… sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1.

When ğ’={Â±1}ğ’³ğ’superscriptplus-or-minus1ğ’³\mathcal{C}=\{\pm 1\}^{\mathcal{X}}caligraphic_C = { Â± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have fâˆ—âˆˆğ’superscriptğ‘“ğ’f^{*}\in\mathcal{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_C and, hence, ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—clean:=minfâˆˆğ’â¢â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯[yâ‰ fâ¢(ğ±)]=0assignsubscriptğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—cleansubscriptğ‘“ğ’subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦Â¯ğ’Ÿğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ±0\mathsf{opt}_{\mathrm{clean}}:=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}% }_{(\mathbf{x},y)\sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]=0sansserif_opt start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_clean end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_f ( bold_x ) ] = 0. âˆ

Appendix C Approximation Theory Results

C.1 Low-Degree Approximators

Our structural TheoremÂ 4.2 can be combined with results from polynomial approximation theory in order to obtain end-to-end results on learning with nasty noise, including the results of TableÂ 2.

Intersections of Halfspaces.

For the class of kğ‘˜kitalic_k-halfspace intersections, [74] showed that the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximate degree with respect to the standard Gaussian distribution ğ’©dsubscriptğ’©ğ‘‘\mathcal{N}_{d}caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see DefinitionÂ 4.1) is â„“â¢(Ïµ)â‰¤Oâ¢(logâ¡(k)/Ïµ2)â„“italic-Ïµğ‘‚ğ‘˜superscriptitalic-Ïµ2\ell(\epsilon)\leq O(\log(k)/\epsilon^{2})roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) â‰¤ italic_O ( roman_log ( italic_k ) / italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and [63] obtains the same result with respect to the uniform distribution UnifdsubscriptUnifğ‘‘\operatorname{Unif}_{d}roman_Unif start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over the hypercube.

Monotone Functions and Convex Sets.

For monotone functions, the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximate degree with respect to UnifdsubscriptUnifğ‘‘\operatorname{Unif}_{d}roman_Unif start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT was bounded by â„“â¢(Ïµ)â‰¤Oâ¢(d/Ïµ)â„“italic-Ïµğ‘‚ğ‘‘italic-Ïµ\ell(\epsilon)\leq O(\sqrt{d}/\epsilon)roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) â‰¤ italic_O ( square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG / italic_Ïµ ) in [14]. For convex sets, [74] showed that the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximate degree with respect to the Gaussian distribution can be bounded via the Gaussian Surface Area (GSA). Combined with the result of [2] on the GSA of convex sets, the corresponding bound is â„“â¢(Ïµ)â‰¤Oâ¢(d/Ïµ2)â„“italic-Ïµğ‘‚ğ‘‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ2\ell(\epsilon)\leq O(\sqrt{d}/\epsilon^{2})roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) â‰¤ italic_O ( square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG / italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Polynomial Threshold Functions.

For the class of degree-kğ‘˜kitalic_k PTFs, the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximate degree with respect to the standard Gaussian was bounded by â„“â¢(Ïµ)â‰¤Oâ¢(k2/Ïµ2)â„“italic-Ïµğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2superscriptitalic-Ïµ2\ell(\epsilon)\leq O(k^{2}/\epsilon^{2})roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) â‰¤ italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) in [60]. In [62], it was shown that â„“â¢(Ïµ)â‰¤kOâ¢(k2)â¢(logâ¡1/Ïµ)Oâ¢(kâ¢logâ¡k)Ïµ2â„“italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘˜ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2superscript1italic-Ïµğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘˜superscriptitalic-Ïµ2\ell(\epsilon)\leq\frac{k^{O(k^{2})}(\log 1/\epsilon)^{O(k\log k)}}{\epsilon^{% 2}}roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_log 1 / italic_Ïµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_k roman_log italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG with respect to the uniform over {Â±1}dsuperscriptplus-or-minus1ğ‘‘\{\pm 1\}^{d}{ Â± 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Low-depth Circuits.

For the class of ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ– ğ–¢0\mathsf{AC}^{0}sansserif_AC start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT circuits of size sğ‘ sitalic_s and depth tğ‘¡titalic_t, the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximate degree is known to be at most â„“â¢(Ïµ)=Oâ¢(logâ¡(s))tâˆ’1â¢logâ¡(1/Ïµ)â„“italic-Ïµğ‘‚superscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡11italic-Ïµ\ell(\epsilon)=O(\log(s))^{t-1}\log(1/\epsilon)roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) = italic_O ( roman_log ( italic_s ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( 1 / italic_Ïµ ), due to the seminal work of [81] and subsequent improvements [88].

C.2 Sandwiching Approximators

For the more challenging problem of learning with heavy contamination, we require the existence of sandwiching approximators (see TheoremÂ 4.4), and show that arbitrary (non-sandwiching) approximators do not suffice (see TheoremÂ 5.2).

Decision Trees of Halfspaces.

For the class of depth-tğ‘¡titalic_t, size-sğ‘ sitalic_s decision trees of halfspaces, [53] showed that the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-sandwiching degree with respect to either the standard Gaussian or the uniform on the hypercube is â„“â¢(Ïµ)â‰¤O~â¢(t4â¢s2Ïµ2)â„“italic-Ïµ~ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘¡4superscriptğ‘ 2superscriptitalic-Ïµ2\ell(\epsilon)\leq\tilde{O}(\frac{t^{4}s^{2}}{\epsilon^{2}})roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) â‰¤ over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( divide start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ).

Low-Depth Circuits.

The Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-sandwiching degree of ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ– ğ–¢0\mathsf{AC}^{0}sansserif_AC start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT circuits of depth tğ‘¡titalic_t and size sğ‘ sitalic_s is known to be at most â„“â¢(Ïµ)â‰¤Oâ¢(logâ¡(s))Oâ¢(t)â¢logâ¡(1/Ïµ)â„“italic-Ïµğ‘‚superscriptğ‘ ğ‘‚ğ‘¡1italic-Ïµ\ell(\epsilon)\leq O(\log(s))^{O(t)}\log(1/\epsilon)roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) â‰¤ italic_O ( roman_log ( italic_s ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( 1 / italic_Ïµ ), due to the celebrated results of [12, 88, 57].

Polynomial Threshold Functions.

The Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-sandwiching degree of degree-kğ‘˜kitalic_k PTFs over the Gaussian was bounded by â„“â¢(Ïµ)â‰¤Okâ¢(Ïµâˆ’4â¢kâ‹…7k)â„“italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘‚ğ‘˜superscriptitalic-Ïµâ‹…4ğ‘˜superscript7ğ‘˜\ell(\epsilon)\leq O_{k}(\epsilon^{-4k\cdot 7^{k}})roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) â‰¤ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 italic_k â‹… 7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) in [87], based on the pseudorandom generator of [61]. Here, Okâ¢(â‹…)subscriptğ‘‚ğ‘˜â‹…O_{k}(\cdot)italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( â‹… ) is hiding a multiplicative factor that scales as an arbitrary function of kğ‘˜kitalic_k. For k=2ğ‘˜2k=2italic_k = 2, the sandwiching degree with respect to the uniform distribution over the hypercube is known to be at most â„“â¢(Ïµ)â‰¤Oâ¢(1/Ïµ9)â„“italic-Ïµğ‘‚1superscriptitalic-Ïµ9\ell(\epsilon)\leq O(1/\epsilon^{9})roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) â‰¤ italic_O ( 1 / italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 9 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) due to [36].

Functions of Halfspaces over Log-Concave Measures.

For arbitrary functions of kğ‘˜kitalic_k halfspaces, the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-sandwiching degree with respect to any log-concave distribution was shown to be at most â„“â¢(Ïµ)â‰¤expâ¡((logâ¡(logâ¡(k)/Ïµ))Oâ¢(k)/Ïµ4)â„“italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘˜italic-Ïµğ‘‚ğ‘˜superscriptitalic-Ïµ4\ell(\epsilon)\leq\exp((\log(\log(k)/\epsilon))^{O(k)}/\epsilon^{4})roman_â„“ ( italic_Ïµ ) â‰¤ roman_exp ( ( roman_log ( roman_log ( italic_k ) / italic_Ïµ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) by [73, 67].

Appendix D Complexity of Learning with Adversarial Label Noise

The computational complexity of agnostic learning (or equivalently learning with adversarial label noise) is much better understood than the complexity of learning with contamination. In this setting, the learner receives i.i.d.Â examples from some labeled distribution ğ’ŸÂ¯Â¯ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathcal{D}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG whose marginal on the feature space ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X is well-behaved (i.e., Gaussian or uniform) and is, otherwise, arbitrary. The goal is to output, with high probability, a hypothesis whose error is at most ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—+Ïµğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—italic-Ïµ\mathsf{opt}+\epsilonsansserif_opt + italic_Ïµ, where ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—=minfâˆˆğ’â¢â„™(ğ±,y)âˆ¼ğ’ŸÂ¯[yâ‰ fâ¢(ğ±)]ğ—ˆğ—‰ğ—subscriptğ‘“ğ’subscriptâ„™similar-toğ±ğ‘¦Â¯ğ’Ÿğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ±\mathsf{opt}=\min_{f\in\mathcal{C}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{P}}_{(\mathbf{x},y)% \sim\bar{\mathcal{D}}}[y\neq f(\mathbf{x})]sansserif_opt = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x , italic_y ) âˆ¼ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_y â‰  italic_f ( bold_x ) ], for some target concept class ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C.

Upper Bounds.

On the upper bound side, [68] showed that any class with bounded â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation degree admits dimension-efficient agnostic learners via low-degree â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT polynomial regression. Several prior and subsequent works provided such bounds for many fundamental classes, based on Fourier or Hermite analysis [81, 14, 25, 60, 62, 63], as well as geometric properties of Gaussian spaces [74]. Note that the usual way to bound the â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation degree, is to first bound the â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation degree and then use Cauchy-Schwarz inequality. This is because bounding the â„’2subscriptâ„’2\mathcal{L}_{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation is usually more analytically convenient. However, this approach does not always give tight results for the degree in terms of the approximation error. In [46], it was shown that â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation bounds over the hypercube can be obtained directly for any function class with bounded noise sensitivity.

Lower Bounds.

The complexity of agnostic learning with respect to Gaussian marginals was shown to be characterized in terms of the â„’1subscriptâ„’1\mathcal{L}_{1}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximation degree for algorithms that fall in the statistical query (SQ) framework by [37], implying the lower bounds of TableÂ 4 for intersections of halfspaces and polynomial threshold functions. For the uniform distribution on the hypercube, a similar characterization was given by [42]. Moreover, [4] showed an information-theoretic lower bound for learning monotone functions even in the realizable setting, implying the lower bound of TableÂ 4 for monotone functions. For ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ– ğ–¢0\mathsf{AC}^{0}sansserif_AC start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT circuits, [65] provided a cryptographic lower bound.
